{"title": "memory-based control with recurrent neural networks", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "partially observed control problems are a challenging aspect of reinforcement learning"], ["BODY", "we extend two related , model-free algorithms for continuous control -- deterministic policy gradient and stochastic value gradient -- to solve partially observed domains using recurrent neural networks trained with backpropagation through time"], ["BODY", "we demonstrate that this approach , coupled with long-short term memory is able to solve a variety of physical control problems exhibiting an assortment of memory requirements"], ["BODY", "these include the short-term integration of information from noisy sensors and the identification of system parameters , as well as long-term memory problems that require preserving information over many time steps"], ["BODY", "we also demonstrate success on a combined exploration and memory problem in the form of a simplified version of the well-known morris water maze task"], ["CONCLUSION", "finally , we show that our approach can deal with high-dimensional observations by learning directly from pixels"], ["CONCLUSION", "we find that recurrent deterministic and stochastic policies are able to learn similarly good solutions to these tasks , including the water maze where the agent must learn effective search strategies ."]], "topics": ["recurrent neural network", "reinforcement learning"]}

{"title": "a metric learning perspective of svm : on the relation of svm and lmnn", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "support vector machines , svms , and the large margin nearest neighbor algorithm , lmnn , are two very popular learning algorithms with quite different learning biases"], ["BODY", "in this paper we bring them into a unified view and show that they have a much stronger relation than what is commonly thought"], ["BODY", "we analyze svms from a metric learning perspective and cast them as a metric learning problem , a view which helps us uncover the relations of the two algorithms"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show that lmnn can be seen as learning a set of local svm-like models in a quadratic space"], ["CONCLUSION", "along the way and inspired by the metric-based interpretation of svm s we derive a novel variant of svms , epsilon-svm , to which lmnn is even more similar"], ["CONCLUSION", "we give a unified view of lmnn and the different svm variants"], ["CONCLUSION", "finally we provide some preliminary experiments on a number of benchmark datasets in which show that epsilon-svm compares favorably both with respect to lmnn and svm ."]], "topics": ["support vector machine"]}
{"title": "tackling over-pruning in variational autoencoders", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "variational autoencoders ( vae ) are directed generative models that learn factorial latent variables"], ["INTRODUCTION", "as noted by burda et al"], ["INTRODUCTION", "( 2015 ) , these models exhibit the problem of factor over-pruning where a significant number of stochastic factors fail to learn anything and become inactive"], ["INTRODUCTION", "this can limit their modeling power and their ability to learn diverse and meaningful latent representations"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we evaluate several methods to address this problem and propose a more effective model-based approach called the epitomic variational autoencoder ( evae )"], ["BODY", "the so-called epitomes of this model are groups of mutually exclusive latent factors that compete to explain the data"], ["BODY", "this approach helps prevent inactive units since each group is pressured to explain the data"], ["CONCLUSION", "we compare the approaches with qualitative and quantitative results on mnist and tfd datasets"], ["CONCLUSION", "our results show that evae makes efficient use of model capacity and generalizes better than vae ."]], "topics": ["calculus of variations", "autoencoder"]}
{"title": "an improved discrete bat algorithm for symmetric and asymmetric traveling salesman problems", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "bat algorithm is a population metaheuristic proposed in 2010 which is based on the echolocation or bio-sonar characteristics of microbats"], ["INTRODUCTION", "since its first implementation , the bat algorithm has been used in a wide range of fields"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we present a discrete version of the bat algorithm to solve the well-known symmetric and asymmetric traveling salesman problems"], ["BODY", "in addition , we propose an improvement in the basic structure of the classic bat algorithm"], ["BODY", "to prove that our proposal is a promising approximation method , we have compared its performance in 37 instances with the results obtained by five different techniques : evolutionary simulated annealing , genetic algorithm , an island based distributed genetic algorithm , a discrete firefly algorithm and an imperialist competitive algorithm"], ["BODY", "in order to obtain fair and rigorous comparisons , we have conducted three different statistical tests along the paper : the student 's $ t $ -test , the holm 's test , and the friedman test"], ["CONCLUSION", "we have also compared the convergence behaviour shown by our proposal with the ones shown by the evolutionary simulated annealing , and the discrete firefly algorithm"], ["CONCLUSION", "the experimentation carried out in this study has shown that the presented improved bat algorithm outperforms significantly all the other alternatives in most of the cases ."]], "topics": ["simulation"]}
{"title": "visual forecasting by imitating dynamics in natural sequences", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we introduce a general framework for visual forecasting , which directly imitates visual sequences without additional supervision"], ["BODY", "as a result , our model can be applied at several semantic levels and does not require any domain knowledge or handcrafted features"], ["BODY", "we achieve this by formulating visual forecasting as an inverse reinforcement learning ( irl ) problem , and directly imitate the dynamics in natural sequences from their raw pixel values"], ["BODY", "the key challenge is the high-dimensional and continuous state-action space that prohibits the application of previous irl algorithms"], ["BODY", "we address this computational bottleneck by extending recent progress in model-free imitation with trainable deep feature representations , which ( 1 ) bypasses the exhaustive state-action pair visits in dynamic programming by using a dual formulation and ( 2 ) avoids explicit state sampling at gradient computation using a deep feature reparametrization"], ["BODY", "this allows us to apply irl at scale and directly imitate the dynamics in high-dimensional continuous visual sequences from the raw pixel values"], ["CONCLUSION", "we evaluate our approach at three different level-of-abstraction , from low level pixels to higher level semantics : future frame generation , action anticipation , visual story forecasting"], ["CONCLUSION", "at all levels , our approach outperforms existing methods ."]], "topics": ["high- and low-level", "reinforcement learning"]}
{"title": "aide : fast and communication efficient distributed optimization", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in this paper , we present two new communication-efficient methods for distributed minimization of an average of functions"], ["BODY", "the first algorithm is an inexact variant of the dane algorithm that allows any local algorithm to return an approximate solution to a local subproblem"], ["BODY", "we show that such a strategy does not affect the theoretical guarantees of dane significantly"], ["BODY", "in fact , our approach can be viewed as a robustification strategy since the method is substantially better behaved than dane on data partition arising in practice"], ["BODY", "it is well known that dane algorithm does not match the communication complexity lower bounds"], ["BODY", "to bridge this gap , we propose an accelerated variant of the first method , called aide , that not only matches the communication lower bounds but can also be implemented using a purely first-order oracle"], ["CONCLUSION", "our empirical results show that aide is superior to other communication efficient algorithms in settings that naturally arise in machine learning applications ."]], "topics": ["approximation algorithm"]}
{"title": "committee-based sample selection for probabilistic classifiers", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in many real-world learning tasks , it is expensive to acquire a sufficient number of labeled examples for training"], ["BODY", "this paper investigates methods for reducing annotation cost by `sample selection '"], ["BODY", "in this approach , during training the learning program examines many unlabeled examples and selects for labeling only those that are most informative at each stage"], ["BODY", "this avoids redundantly labeling examples that contribute little new information"], ["BODY", "our work follows on previous research on query by committee , extending the committee-based paradigm to the context of probabilistic classification"], ["BODY", "we describe a family of empirical methods for committee-based sample selection in probabilistic classification models , which evaluate the informativeness of an example by measuring the degree of disagreement between several model variants"], ["BODY", "these variants ( the committee ) are drawn randomly from a probability distribution conditioned by the training set labeled so far"], ["BODY", "the method was applied to the real-world natural language processing task of stochastic part-of-speech tagging"], ["CONCLUSION", "we find that all variants of the method achieve a significant reduction in annotation cost , although their computational efficiency differs"], ["CONCLUSION", "in particular , the simplest variant , a two member committee with no parameters to tune , gives excellent results"], ["CONCLUSION", "we also show that sample selection yields a significant reduction in the size of the model used by the tagger ."]], "topics": ["natural language processing"]}

{"title": "optimization as estimation with gaussian processes in bandit settings", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "recently , there has been rising interest in bayesian optimization -- the optimization of an unknown function with assumptions usually expressed by a gaussian process ( gp ) prior"], ["BODY", "we study an optimization strategy that directly uses an estimate of the argmax of the function"], ["BODY", "this strategy offers both practical and theoretical advantages : no tradeoff parameter needs to be selected , and , moreover , we establish close connections to the popular gp-ucb and gp-pi strategies"], ["BODY", "our approach can be understood as automatically and adaptively trading off exploration and exploitation in gp-ucb and gp-pi"], ["CONCLUSION", "we illustrate the effects of this adaptive tuning via bounds on the regret as well as an extensive empirical evaluation on robotics and vision tasks , demonstrating the robustness of this strategy for a range of performance criteria ."]], "topics": ["regret ( decision theory )", "mathematical optimization"]}
{"title": "fast meta-learning for adaptive hierarchical classifier design", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose a new splitting criterion for a meta-learning approach to multiclass classifier design that adaptively merges the classes into a tree-structured hierarchy of increasingly difficult binary classification problems"], ["BODY", "the classification tree is constructed from empirical estimates of the henze-penrose bounds on the pairwise bayes misclassification rates that rank the binary subproblems in terms of difficulty of classification"], ["BODY", "the proposed empirical estimates of the bayes error rate are computed from the minimal spanning tree ( mst ) of the samples from each pair of classes"], ["BODY", "moreover , a meta-learning technique is presented for quantifying the one-vs-rest bayes error rate for each individual class from a single mst on the entire dataset"], ["CONCLUSION", "extensive simulations on benchmark datasets show that the proposed hierarchical method can often be learned much faster than competing methods , while achieving competitive accuracy ."]], "topics": ["simulation", "eisenstein 's criterion"]}
{"title": "retinal vessel segmentation using the 2-d morlet wavelet and supervised classification", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we present a method for automated segmentation of the vasculature in retinal images"], ["BODY", "the method produces segmentations by classifying each image pixel as vessel or non-vessel , based on the pixel 's feature vector"], ["BODY", "feature vectors are composed of the pixel 's intensity and continuous two-dimensional morlet wavelet transform responses taken at multiple scales"], ["BODY", "the morlet wavelet is capable of tuning to specific frequencies , thus allowing noise filtering and vessel enhancement in a single step"], ["BODY", "we use a bayesian classifier with class-conditional probability density functions ( likelihoods ) described as gaussian mixtures , yielding a fast classification , while being able to model complex decision surfaces and compare its performance with the linear minimum squared error classifier"], ["BODY", "the probability distributions are estimated based on a training set of labeled pixels obtained from manual segmentations"], ["BODY", "the method 's performance is evaluated on publicly available drive and stare databases of manually labeled non-mydriatic images"], ["CONCLUSION", "on the drive database , it achieves an area under the receiver operating characteristic ( roc ) curve of 0.9598 , being slightly superior than that presented by the method of staal et al ."]], "topics": ["image segmentation", "feature vector"]}
{"title": "map-based multi-policy reinforcement learning : enhancing adaptability of robots by deep reinforcement learning", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in order for robots to perform mission-critical tasks , it is essential that they are able to quickly adapt to changes in their environment as well as to injuries and or other bodily changes"], ["INTRODUCTION", "deep reinforcement learning has been shown to be successful in training robot control policies for operation in complex environments"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , existing methods typically employ only a single policy"], ["INTRODUCTION", "this can limit the adaptability since a large environmental modification might require a completely different behavior compared to the learning environment"], ["BODY", "to solve this problem , we propose map-based multi-policy reinforcement learning ( mmprl ) , which aims to search and store multiple policies that encode different behavioral features while maximizing the expected reward in advance of the environment change"], ["BODY", "thanks to these policies , which are stored into a multi-dimensional discrete map according to its behavioral feature , adaptation can be performed within reasonable time without retraining the robot"], ["BODY", "an appropriate pre-trained policy from the map can be recalled using bayesian optimization"], ["CONCLUSION", "our experiments show that mmprl enables robots to quickly adapt to large changes without requiring any prior knowledge on the type of injuries that could occur"], ["CONCLUSION", "a highlight of the learned behaviors can be found here : https : //youtu.be/qwinbilxnoe ."]], "topics": ["reinforcement learning", "robot"]}

{"title": "learning heuristic search via imitation", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "robotic motion planning problems are typically solved by constructing a search tree of valid maneuvers from a start to a goal configuration"], ["INTRODUCTION", "limited onboard computation and real-time planning constraints impose a limit on how large this search tree can grow"], ["INTRODUCTION", "heuristics play a crucial role in such situations by guiding the search towards potentially good directions and consequently minimizing search effort"], ["INTRODUCTION", "moreover , it must infer such directions in an efficient manner using only the information uncovered by the search up until that time"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , state of the art methods do not address the problem of computing a heuristic that explicitly minimizes search effort"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we do so by training a heuristic policy that maps the partial information from the search to decide which node of the search tree to expand"], ["BODY", "unfortunately , naively training such policies leads to slow convergence and poor local minima"], ["BODY", "we present sail , an efficient algorithm that trains heuristic policies by imitating `` clairvoyant oracles '' - oracles that have full information about the world and demonstrate decisions that minimize search effort"], ["BODY", "we leverage the fact that such oracles can be efficiently computed using dynamic programming and derive performance guarantees for the learnt heuristic"], ["BODY", "we validate the approach on a spectrum of environments which show that sail consistently outperforms state of the art algorithms"], ["CONCLUSION", "our approach paves the way forward for learning heuristics that demonstrate an anytime nature - finding feasible solutions quickly and incrementally refining it over time ."]], "topics": ["heuristic", "computation"]}
{"title": "towards synthesizing complex programs from input-output examples", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in recent years , deep learning techniques have been developed to improve the performance of program synthesis from input-output examples"], ["INTRODUCTION", "albeit its significant progress , the programs that can be synthesized by state-of-the-art approaches are still simple in terms of their complexity"], ["BODY", "in this work , we move a significant step forward along this direction by proposing a new class of challenging tasks in the domain of program synthesis from input-output examples : learning a context-free parser from pairs of input programs and their parse trees"], ["BODY", "we show that this class of tasks are much more challenging than previously studied tasks , and the test accuracy of existing approaches is almost 0 %"], ["BODY", "we tackle the challenges by developing three novel techniques inspired by three novel observations , which reveal the key ingredients of using deep learning to synthesize a complex program"], ["BODY", "first , the use of a non-differentiable machine is the key to effectively restrict the search space"], ["BODY", "thus our proposed approach learns a neural program operating a domain-specific non-differentiable machine"], ["BODY", "second , recursion is the key to achieve generalizability"], ["BODY", "thus , we bake-in the notion of recursion in the design of our non-differentiable machine"], ["BODY", "third , reinforcement learning is the key to learn how to operate the non-differentiable machine , but it is also hard to train the model effectively with existing reinforcement learning algorithms from a cold boot"], ["BODY", "we develop a novel two-phase reinforcement learning-based search algorithm to overcome this issue"], ["CONCLUSION", "in our evaluation , we show that using our novel approach , neural parsing programs can be learned to achieve 100 % test accuracy on test inputs that are 500x longer than the training samples ."]], "topics": ["reinforcement learning", "parsing"]}
{"title": "training generative adversarial networks via primal-dual subgradient methods : a lagrangian perspective on gan", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we relate the minimax game of generative adversarial networks ( gans ) to finding the saddle points of the lagrangian function for a convex optimization problem , where the discriminator outputs and the distribution of generator outputs play the roles of primal variables and dual variables , respectively"], ["BODY", "this formulation shows the connection between the standard gan training process and the primal-dual subgradient methods for convex optimization"], ["BODY", "the inherent connection does not only provide a theoretical convergence proof for training gans in the function space , but also inspires a novel objective function for training"], ["BODY", "the modified objective function forces the distribution of generator outputs to be updated along the direction according to the primal-dual subgradient methods"], ["CONCLUSION", "a toy example shows that the proposed method is able to resolve mode collapse , which in this case can not be avoided by the standard gan or wasserstein gan"], ["CONCLUSION", "experiments on both gaussian mixture synthetic data and real-world image datasets demonstrate the performance of the proposed method on generating diverse samples ."]], "topics": ["optimization problem", "loss function"]}

{"title": "data augmentation of railway images for track inspection", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "regular maintenance of all the assets is pivotal for proper functioning of railway"], ["INTRODUCTION", "manual maintenance can be very cumbersome and leave room for errors"], ["INTRODUCTION", "track anomalies like vegetation overgrowth , sun kinks affect the track construct and result in unequal load transfer , imbalanced lateral forces on tracks which causes further deterioration of tracks and can ultimately result in derailment of locomotive"], ["INTRODUCTION", "hence there is a need to continuously monitor rail track health"], ["INTRODUCTION", "track anomalies are rare with the skew as high as one anomaly in millions of good images"], ["BODY", "we propose a method to build training data that will make our algorithms more robust and help us detect real world track issues"], ["BODY", "the data augmentation will have a direct effect in making us detect better anomalies and hence improve time for railroads that is spent in manual inspection"], ["BODY", "this paper talks about a real world use case of detecting railway track defects from a camera mounted on a moving locomotive and tracking their locations"], ["BODY", "the camera is engineered to withstand the environment factors on a moving train and provide a consistent steady image at around 30 frames per second"], ["BODY", "an image simulation pipeline of track detection , region of interest selection , augmenting image for anomalies is implemented"], ["BODY", "training images are simulated for sun kink and vegetation overgrowth"], ["BODY", "inception v3 model pretrained on imagenet dataset is finetuned for a 2 class classification"], ["BODY", "for the case of vegetation overgrowth , the model {"title": "red : reinforced encoder-decoder networks for action anticipation", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "action anticipation aims to detect an action before it happens"], ["INTRODUCTION", "many real world applications in robotics and surveillance are related to this predictive capability"], ["INTRODUCTION", "current methods address this problem by first anticipating visual representations of future frames and then categorizing the anticipated representations to actions"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , anticipation is based on a single past frame 's representation , which ignores the history trend"], ["INTRODUCTION", "besides , it can only anticipate a fixed future time"], ["BODY", "we propose a reinforced encoder-decoder ( red ) network for action anticipation"], ["BODY", "red takes multiple history representations as input and learns to anticipate a sequence of future representations"], ["BODY", "one salient aspect of red is that a reinforcement module is adopted to provide sequence-level supervision ; the reward function is designed to encourage the system to make correct predictions as early as possible"], ["CONCLUSION", "we test red on tvseries , thumos-14 and tv-human-interaction datasets for action anticipation and achieve state-of-the-art performance on all datasets ."]], "topics": ["reinforcement learning", "encoder"]}
{"title": "efficient sampling for k-determinantal point processes", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "determinantal point processes ( dpps ) are elegant probabilistic models of repulsion and diversity over discrete sets of items"], ["INTRODUCTION", "but their applicability to large sets is hindered by expensive cubic-complexity matrix operations for basic tasks such as sampling"], ["BODY", "in light of this , we propose a new method for approximate sampling from discrete $ k $ -dpps"], ["BODY", "our method takes advantage of the diversity property of subsets sampled from a dpp , and proceeds in two stages : first it constructs coresets for the ground set of items ; thereafter , it efficiently samples subsets based on the constructed coresets"], ["BODY", "as opposed to previous approaches , our algorithm aims to minimize the total variation distance to the original distribution"], ["CONCLUSION", "experiments on both synthetic and real datasets indicate that our sampling algorithm works efficiently on large data sets , and yields more accurate samples than previous approaches ."]], "topics": ["sampling ( signal processing )", "approximation algorithm"]}
{"title": "neutro-connectedness cut", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "interactive image segmentation is a challenging task and receives increasing attention recently ; however , two major drawbacks exist in interactive segmentation approaches"], ["INTRODUCTION", "first , the segmentation performance of roi-based methods is sensitive to the initial roi : different rois may produce results with great difference"], ["INTRODUCTION", "second , most seed-based methods need intense interactions , and are not applicable in many cases"], ["BODY", "in this work , we generalize the neutro-connectedness ( nc ) to be independent of top-down priors of objects and to model image topology with indeterminacy measurement on image regions , propose a novel method for determining object and background regions , which is applied to exclude isolated background regions and enforce label consistency , and put forward a hybrid interactive segmentation method , neutro-connectedness cut ( nc-cut ) , which can overcome the above two problems by utilizing both pixel-wise appearance information and region-based nc properties"], ["BODY", "we evaluate the proposed nc-cut by employing two image datasets ( 265 images ) , and demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art interactive image segmentation methods ( grabcut , milcut , one-cut , mgc_max^sum and ppbc ) ."]], "topics": ["image segmentation", "interaction"]}
{"title": "clustering of data with missing entries using non-convex fusion penalties", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the presence of missing entries in data often creates challenges for pattern recognition algorithms"], ["INTRODUCTION", "traditional algorithms for clustering data assume that all the feature values are known for every data point"], ["BODY", "we propose a method to cluster data in the presence of missing information"], ["BODY", "unlike conventional clustering techniques where every feature is known for each point , our algorithm can handle cases where a few feature values are unknown for every point"], ["BODY", "for this more challenging problem , we provide theoretical guarantees for clustering using a $ \\ell_0 $ fusion penalty based optimization problem"], ["BODY", "furthermore , we propose an algorithm to solve a relaxation of this problem using saturating non-convex fusion penalties"], ["CONCLUSION", "it is observed that this algorithm produces solutions that degrade gradually with an increase in the fraction of missing feature values"], ["CONCLUSION", "we demonstrate the utility of the proposed method using a simulated dataset , the wine dataset and also an under-sampled cardiac mri dataset"], ["CONCLUSION", "it is shown that the proposed method is a promising clustering technique for datasets with large fractions of missing entries ."]], "topics": ["cluster analysis", "optimization problem"]}

{"title": "an online learning algorithm for neuromorphic hardware implementation", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose a sign-based online learning ( sol ) algorithm for a neuromorphic hardware framework called trainable analogue block ( tab )"], ["BODY", "the tab framework utilises the principles of neural population coding , implying that it encodes the input stimulus using a large pool of nonlinear neurons"], ["BODY", "the sol algorithm is a simple weight update rule that employs the sign of the hidden layer activation and the sign of the output error , which is the difference between the target output and the predicted output"], ["BODY", "the sol algorithm is easily implementable in hardware , and can be used in any artificial neural network framework that learns weights by minimising a convex cost function"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show that the tab framework can be trained for various regression tasks using the sol algorithm ."]], "topics": ["nonlinear system", "loss function"]}
{"title": "sparsity assisted solution to the twin image problem in phase retrieval", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the iterative phase retrieval problem for complex-valued objects from fourier transform magnitude data is known to suffer from the twin image problem"], ["INTRODUCTION", "in particular , when the object support is centro-symmetric , the iterative solution often stagnates such that the resultant complex image contains the features of both the desired solution and its inverted and complex-conjugated replica"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the conventional approach to address the twin image problem is to modify the object support during initial iterations which can possibly lead to elimination of one of the twin images"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , at present there seems to be no deterministic procedure to make sure that the twin image will always be very weak or absent"], ["BODY", "in this work we make an important observation that the ideal solution without the twin image is typically more sparse ( in some suitable transform domain ) as compared to the stagnated solution containing the twin image"], ["CONCLUSION", "we further show that introducing a sparsity enhancing step in the iterative algorithm can address the twin image problem without the need to change the object support throughout the iterative process even when the object support is centro-symmetric"], ["CONCLUSION", "in a simulation study , we use binary and gray-scale pure phase objects and illustrate the effectiveness of the sparsity assisted phase recovery in the context of the twin image problem"], ["CONCLUSION", "the results have important implications for a wide range of topics in physics where the phase retrieval problem plays a central role ."]], "topics": ["simulation", "iteration"]}
{"title": "unsupervised domain adaptation in the wild : dealing with asymmetric label sets", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the goal of domain adaptation is to adapt models learned on a source domain to a particular target domain"], ["INTRODUCTION", "most methods for unsupervised domain adaptation proposed in the literature to date , assume that the set of classes present in the target domain is identical to the set of classes present in the source domain"], ["INTRODUCTION", "this is a restrictive assumption that limits the practical applicability of unsupervised domain adaptation techniques in real world settings ( `` in the wild '' )"], ["BODY", "therefore , we relax this constraint and propose a technique that allows the set of target classes to be a subset of the source classes"], ["BODY", "this way , large publicly available annotated datasets with a wide variety of classes can be used as source , even if the actual set of classes in target can be more limited and , maybe most importantly , unknown beforehand"], ["BODY", "to this end , we propose an algorithm that orders a set of source subspaces that are relevant to the target classification problem"], ["BODY", "our method then chooses a restricted set from this ordered set of source subspaces"], ["BODY", "as an extension , even starting from multiple source datasets with varied sets of categories , this method automatically selects an appropriate subset of source categories relevant to a target dataset"], ["CONCLUSION", "empirical analysis on a number of source and target domain datasets shows that restricting the source subspace to only a subset of categories does indeed substantially improve the eventual target classification accuracy over the baseline that considers all source classes ."]], "topics": ["baseline ( configuration management )", "unsupervised learning"]}

{"title": "multiple hypothesis colorization", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in this work we focus on the problem of colorization for image compression"], ["BODY", "since color information occupies a large proportion of the total storage size of an image , a method that can predict accurate color from its grayscale version can produce dramatic reduction in image file size"], ["BODY", "but colorization for compression poses several challenges"], ["BODY", "first , while colorization for artistic purposes simply involves predicting plausible chroma , colorization for compression requires generating output colors that are as close as possible to the ground truth"], ["BODY", "second , many objects in the real world exhibit multiple possible colors"], ["BODY", "thus , to disambiguate the colorization problem some additional information must be stored to reproduce the true colors with good accuracy"], ["BODY", "to account for the multimodal color distribution of objects we propose a deep tree-structured network that generates multiple color hypotheses for every pixel from a grayscale picture ( as opposed to a single color produced by most prior colorization approaches )"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show how to leverage the multimodal output of our model to reproduce with high fidelity the true colors of an image by storing very little additional information"], ["CONCLUSION", "in the experiments we show that our proposed method outperforms traditional jpeg color coding by a large margin , producing colors that are nearly indistinguishable from the ground truth at the storage cost of just a few hundred bytes for high-resolution pictures !"]], "topics": ["ground truth", "pixel"]}

{"title": "the incredible shrinking neural network : new perspectives on learning representations through the lens of pruning", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "how much can pruning algorithms teach us about the fundamentals of learning representations in neural networks ? and how much can these fundamentals help while devising new pruning techniques ? a lot , it turns out"], ["INTRODUCTION", "neural network pruning has become a topic of great interest in recent years , and many different techniques have been proposed to address this problem"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the decision of what to prune and when to prune necessarily forces us to confront our assumptions about how neural networks actually learn to represent patterns in data"], ["BODY", "in this work , we set out to test several long-held hypotheses about neural network learning representations , approaches to pruning and the relevance of one in the context of the other"], ["BODY", "to accomplish this , we argue in favor of pruning whole neurons as opposed to the traditional method of pruning weights from optimally trained networks"], ["BODY", "we first review the historical literature , point out some common assumptions it makes , and propose methods to demonstrate the inherent flaws in these assumptions"], ["BODY", "we then propose our novel approach to pruning and set about analyzing the quality of the decisions it makes"], ["CONCLUSION", "our analysis led us to question the validity of many widely-held assumptions behind pruning algorithms and the trade-offs we often make in the interest of reducing computational complexity"], ["CONCLUSION", "we discovered that there is a straightforward way , however expensive , to serially prune 40-70 % of the neurons in a trained network with minimal effect on the learning representation and without any re-training"], ["CONCLUSION", "it is to be noted here that the motivation behind this work is not to propose an algorithm that would outperform all existing methods , but to shed light on what some inherent flaws in these methods can teach us about learning representations and how this can lead us to superior pruning techniques ."]], "topics": ["feature learning", "computational complexity theory"]}
{"title": "adaptive representation selection in contextual bandit with unlabeled history", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we consider an extension of the contextual bandit setting , motivated by several practical applications , where an unlabeled history of contexts can become available for pre-training before the online decision-making begins"], ["BODY", "we propose an approach for improving the performance of contextual bandit in such setting , via adaptive , dynamic representation learning , which combines offline pre-training on unlabeled history of contexts with online selection and modification of embedding functions"], ["CONCLUSION", "our experiments on a variety of datasets and in different nonstationary environments demonstrate clear advantages of our approach over the standard contextual bandit ."]], "topics": ["feature learning"]}
{"title": "efficient interactive annotation of segmentation datasets with polygon-rnn++", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "manually labeling datasets with object masks is extremely time consuming"], ["BODY", "in this work , we follow the idea of polygon-rnn to produce polygonal annotations of objects interactively using humans-in-the-loop"], ["BODY", "we introduce several important improvements to the model : 1 ) we design a new cnn encoder architecture , 2 ) show how to effectively train the model with reinforcement learning , and 3 ) significantly increase the output resolution using a graph neural network , allowing the model to accurately annotate high-resolution objects in images"], ["BODY", "extensive evaluation on the cityscapes dataset shows that our model , which we refer to as polygon-rnn++ , significantly outperforms the original model in both automatic ( 10 % absolute and 16 % relative improvement in mean iou ) and interactive modes ( requiring 50 % fewer clicks by annotators )"], ["CONCLUSION", "we further analyze the cross-domain scenario in which our model is trained on one dataset , and used out of the box on datasets from varying domains"], ["CONCLUSION", "the results show that polygon-rnn++ exhibits powerful generalization capabilities , achieving significant improvements over existing pixel-wise methods"], ["CONCLUSION", "using simple online fine-tuning we further achieve a high reduction in annotation time for new datasets , moving a step closer towards an interactive annotation tool to be used in practice ."]], "topics": ["reinforcement learning", "encoder"]}
{"title": "maximally informative hierarchical representations of high-dimensional data", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we consider a set of probabilistic functions of some input variables as a representation of the inputs"], ["BODY", "we present bounds on how informative a representation is about input data"], ["BODY", "we extend these bounds to hierarchical representations so that we can quantify the contribution of each layer towards capturing the information in the original data"], ["BODY", "the special form of these bounds leads to a simple , bottom-up optimization procedure to construct hierarchical representations that are also maximally informative about the data"], ["BODY", "this optimization has linear computational complexity and constant sample complexity in the number of variables"], ["CONCLUSION", "these results establish a new approach to unsupervised learning of deep representations that is both principled and practical"], ["CONCLUSION", "we demonstrate the usefulness of the approach on both synthetic and real-world data ."]], "topics": ["feature learning", "computational complexity theory"]}
{"title": "enhancing the performance of convolutional neural networks on quality degraded datasets", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "despite the appeal of deep neural networks that largely replace the traditional handmade filters , they still suffer from isolated cases that can not be properly handled only by the training of convolutional filters"], ["INTRODUCTION", "abnormal factors , including real-world noise , blur , or other quality degradations , ruin the output of a neural network"], ["INTRODUCTION", "these unexpected problems can produce critical complications , and it is surprising that there has only been minimal research into the effects of noise in the deep neural network model"], ["BODY", "therefore , we present an exhaustive investigation into the effect of noise in image classification and suggest a generalized architecture of a dual-channel model to treat quality degraded input images"], ["BODY", "we compare the proposed dual-channel model with a simple single model and show it improves the overall performance of neural networks on various types of quality degraded input datasets ."]], "topics": ["neural networks", "computer vision"]}
{"title": "facial landmarks detection by self-iterative regression based landmarks-attention network", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "cascaded regression ( cr ) based methods have been proposed to solve facial landmarks detection problem , which learn a series of descent directions by multiple cascaded regressors separately trained in coarse and fine stages"], ["INTRODUCTION", "they outperform the traditional gradient descent based methods in both accuracy and running speed"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , cascaded regression is not robust enough because each regressor 's training data comes from the output of previous regressor"], ["INTRODUCTION", "moreover , training multiple regressors requires lots of computing resources , especially for deep learning based methods"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we develop a self-iterative regression ( sir ) framework to improve the model efficiency"], ["BODY", "only one self-iterative regressor is trained to learn the descent directions for samples from coarse stages to fine stages , and parameters are iteratively updated by the same regressor"], ["BODY", "specifically , we proposed landmarks-attention network ( lan ) as our regressor , which concurrently learns features around each landmark and obtains the holistic location increment"], ["BODY", "by doing so , not only the rest of regressors are removed to simplify the training process , but the number of model parameters is significantly decreased"], ["CONCLUSION", "the experiments demonstrate that with only 3.72m model parameters , our proposed method achieves the state-of-the-art performance ."]], "topics": ["test set", "gradient descent"]}
{"title": "similarity-based models of word cooccurrence probabilities", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in many applications of natural language processing ( nlp ) it is necessary to determine the likelihood of a given word combination"], ["INTRODUCTION", "for example , a speech recognizer may need to determine which of the two word combinations `` eat a peach '' and `` eat a beach '' is more likely"], ["INTRODUCTION", "statistical nlp methods determine the likelihood of a word combination from its frequency in a training corpus"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , the nature of language is such that many word combinations are infrequent and do not occur in any given corpus"], ["BODY", "in this work we propose a method for estimating the probability of such previously unseen word combinations using available information on `` most similar '' words"], ["BODY", "we describe probabilistic word association models based on distributional word similarity , and apply them to two tasks , language modeling and pseudo-word disambiguation"], ["BODY", "in the language modeling task , a similarity-based model is used to improve probability estimates for unseen bigrams in a back-off language model"], ["CONCLUSION", "the similarity-based method yields a 20 % perplexity improvement in the prediction of unseen bigrams and statistically significant reductions in speech-recognition error"], ["CONCLUSION", "we also compare four similarity-based estimation methods against back-off and maximum-likelihood estimation methods on a pseudo-word sense disambiguation task in which we controlled for both unigram and bigram frequency to avoid giving too much weight to easy-to-disambiguate high-frequency configurations"], ["CONCLUSION", "the similarity-based methods perform up to 40 % better on this particular task ."]], "topics": ["natural language processing", "natural language"]}
{"title": "a novel brain decoding method : a correlation network framework for revealing brain connections", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "brain decoding is a hot spot in cognitive science , which focuses on reconstructing perceptual images from brain activities"], ["INTRODUCTION", "analyzing the correlations of collected data from human brain activities and representing activity patterns are two problems in brain decoding based on functional magnetic resonance imaging ( fmri ) signals"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , existing correlation analysis methods mainly focus on the strength information of voxel , which reveals functional connectivity in the cerebral cortex"], ["INTRODUCTION", "they tend to neglect the structural information that implies the intracortical or intrinsic connections ; that is , structural connectivity"], ["INTRODUCTION", "hence , the effective connectivity inferred by these methods is relatively unilateral"], ["BODY", "therefore , we proposed a correlation network ( corrnet ) framework that could be flexibly combined with diverse pattern representation models"], ["BODY", "in the corrnet framework , the topological correlation was introduced to reveal structural information"], ["BODY", "rich correlations were obtained , which contributed to specifying the underlying effective connectivity"], ["BODY", "we also combined the corrnet framework with a linear support vector machine ( svm ) and a dynamic evolving spike neuron network ( snn ) for pattern representation separately , thus providing a novel method for decoding cognitive activity patterns"], ["CONCLUSION", "experimental results verified the reliability and robustness of our corrnet framework and demonstrated that the new method achieved significant improvement in brain decoding over comparable methods ."]], "topics": ["support vector machine"]}
{"title": "optimal shrinkage of singular values under random data contamination", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "a low rank matrix x has been contaminated by uniformly distributed noise , missing values , outliers and corrupt entries"], ["INTRODUCTION", "reconstruction of x from the singular values and singular vectors of the contaminated matrix y is a key problem in machine learning , computer vision and data science"], ["BODY", "in this paper we show that common contamination models ( including arbitrary combinations of uniform noise , missing values , outliers and corrupt entries ) can be described efficiently using a single framework"], ["BODY", "we develop an asymptotically optimal algorithm that estimates x by manipulation of the singular values of y , which applies to any of the contamination models considered"], ["BODY", "finally , we find an explicit signal-to-noise cutoff , below which estimation of x from the singular value decomposition of y must fail , in a well-defined sense ."]], "topics": ["computer vision"]}
{"title": "combinatorial multi-objective multi-armed bandit problem", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in this paper , we introduce the combinatorial multi-objective multi-armed bandit ( como-mab ) problem that captures the challenges of combinatorial and multi-objective online learning simultaneously"], ["BODY", "in this setting , the goal of the learner is to choose an action at each time , whose reward vector is a linear combination of the reward vectors of the arms in the action , to learn the set of super pareto optimal actions , which includes the pareto optimal actions and actions that become pareto optimal after adding an arbitrary small positive number to their expected reward vectors"], ["BODY", "we define the pareto regret performance metric and propose a fair learning algorithm whose pareto regret is $ o ( n l^3 \\log t ) $ , where $ t $ is the time horizon , $ n $ is the number of arms and $ l $ is the maximum number of arms in an action"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show that como-mab has a wide range of applications , including recommending bundles of items to users and network routing , and focus on a resource-allocation application for multi-user communication in the presence of multidimensional performance metrics , where we show that our algorithm outperforms existing mab algorithms ."]], "topics": ["regret ( decision theory )"]}
{"title": "the k-nearest neighbour ucb algorithm for multi-armed bandits with covariates", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in this paper we propose and explore the k-nearest neighbour ucb algorithm for multi-armed bandits with covariates"], ["BODY", "we focus on a setting where the covariates are supported on a metric space of low intrinsic dimension , such as a manifold embedded within a high dimensional ambient feature space"], ["BODY", "the algorithm is conceptually simple and straightforward to implement"], ["BODY", "the k-nearest neighbour ucb algorithm does not require prior knowledge of the either the intrinsic dimension of the marginal distribution or the time horizon"], ["CONCLUSION", "we prove a regret bound for the k-nearest neighbour ucb algorithm which is minimax optimal up to logarithmic factors"], ["CONCLUSION", "in particular , the algorithm automatically takes advantage of both low intrinsic dimensionality of the marginal distribution over the covariates and low noise in the data , expressed as a margin condition"], ["CONCLUSION", "in addition , focusing on the case of bounded rewards , we give corresponding regret bounds for the k-nearest neighbour kl-ucb algorithm , which is an analogue of the kl-ucb algorithm adapted to the setting of multi-armed bandits with covariates"], ["CONCLUSION", "finally , we present empirical results which demonstrate the ability of both the k-nearest neighbour ucb and k-nearest neighbour kl-ucb to take advantage of situations where the data is supported on an unknown sub-manifold of a high-dimensional feature space ."]], "topics": ["regret ( decision theory )", "feature vector"]}
{"title": "random feature expansions for deep gaussian processes", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the composition of multiple gaussian processes as a deep gaussian process ( dgp ) enables a deep probabilistic nonparametric approach to flexibly tackle complex machine learning problems with sound quantification of uncertainty"], ["INTRODUCTION", "existing inference approaches for dgp models have limited scalability and are notoriously cumbersome to construct"], ["BODY", "in this work , we introduce a novel formulation of dgps based on random feature expansions that we train using stochastic variational inference"], ["BODY", "this yields a practical learning framework which significantly advances the state-of-the-art in inference for dgps , and enables accurate quantification of uncertainty"], ["CONCLUSION", "we extensively showcase the scalability and performance of our proposal on several datasets with up to 8 million observations , and various dgp architectures with up to 30 hidden layers ."]], "topics": ["calculus of variations", "scalability"]}
{"title": "uncertainty estimates for optical flow with multi-hypotheses networks", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "recent work has shown that optical flow estimation can be formulated as an end-to-end supervised learning problem , which yields estimates with a superior accuracy-runtime tradeoff compared to alternative methodology"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we make the network estimate its local uncertainty about the correctness of its prediction , which is vital information when building decisions on top of the estimated optical flow"], ["BODY", "for the first time we compare several strategies and techniques to estimate uncertainty in a large-scale computer vision task like optical flow estimation"], ["BODY", "moreover , we introduce a new network architecture that enforces complementary hypotheses and provides uncertainty estimates efficiently within a single forward pass without the need for sampling or ensembles"], ["CONCLUSION", "we demonstrate high-quality uncertainty estimates that clearly improve over previous confidence measures on optical flow and allow for interactive frame rates ."]], "topics": ["sampling ( signal processing )", "supervised learning"]}

events in a stream , we utilized the lstm model by rendering it for the activity segmentation"], ["BODY", "then , the inferred boundaries were revised by our validation algorithm for a bit shifted boundaries"], ["CONCLUSION", "our experiments show the surprising result of high accuracy above 95 % , on our own testbed with various smart objects"], ["CONCLUSION", "this is superior to the prior {"title": "theory and tools for the conversion of analog to spiking convolutional neural networks", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "deep convolutional neural networks ( cnns ) have shown great potential for numerous real-world machine learning applications , but performing inference in large cnns in real-time remains a challenge"], ["INTRODUCTION", "we have previously demonstrated that traditional cnns can be converted into deep spiking neural networks ( snns ) , which exhibit similar accuracy while reducing both latency and computational load as a consequence of their data-driven , event-based style of computing"], ["BODY", "here we provide a novel theory that explains why this conversion is successful , and derive from it several new tools to convert a larger and more powerful class of deep networks into snns"], ["BODY", "we identify the main sources of approximation errors in previous conversion methods , and propose simple mechanisms to fix these issues"], ["BODY", "furthermore , we develop spiking implementations of common cnn operations such as max-pooling , softmax , and batch-normalization , which allow almost loss-less conversion of arbitrary cnn architectures into the spiking domain"], ["CONCLUSION", "empirical evaluation of different network architectures on the mnist and cifar10 benchmarks leads to the best snn results reported to date ."]], "topics": ["neural networks", "mnist database"]}
{"title": "non-convex rank minimization via an empirical bayesian approach", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in many applications that require matrix solutions of minimal rank , the underlying cost function is non-convex leading to an intractable , np-hard optimization problem"], ["INTRODUCTION", "consequently , the convex nuclear norm is frequently used as a surrogate penalty term for matrix rank"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the problem is that in many practical scenarios there is no longer any guarantee that we can correctly estimate generative low-rank matrices of interest , theoretical special cases notwithstanding"], ["BODY", "consequently , this paper proposes an alternative empirical bayesian procedure build upon a variational approximation that , unlike the nuclear norm , retains the same globally minimizing point estimate as the rank function under many useful constraints"], ["BODY", "however , locally minimizing solutions are largely smoothed away via marginalization , allowing the algorithm to succeed when standard convex relaxations completely fail"], ["BODY", "while the proposed methodology is generally applicable to a wide range of low-rank applications , we focus our attention on the robust principal component analysis problem ( rpca ) , which involves estimating an unknown low-rank matrix with unknown sparse corruptions"], ["CONCLUSION", "theoretical and empirical evidence are presented to show that our method is potentially superior to related map-based approaches , for which the convex principle component pursuit ( pcp ) algorithm ( candes et al"], ["CONCLUSION", ", 2011 ) can be viewed as a special case ."]], "topics": ["optimization problem", "calculus of variations"]}

{"title": "improving human activity recognition through ranking and re-ranking", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose two well-motivated ranking-based methods to enhance the performance of current state-of-the-art human activity recognition systems"], ["BODY", "first , as an improvement over the classic power normalization method , we propose a parameter-free ranking technique called rank normalization ( ran )"], ["BODY", "ran normalizes each dimension of the video features to address the sparse and bursty distribution problems of fisher vectors and vlad"], ["BODY", "second , inspired by curriculum learning , we introduce a training-free re-ranking technique called multi-class iterative re-ranking ( mir )"], ["BODY", "mir captures relationships among action classes by separating easy and typical videos from difficult ones and re-ranking the prediction scores of classifiers accordingly"], ["CONCLUSION", "we demonstrate that our methods significantly improve the performance of state-of-the-art motion features on six real-world datasets ."]], "topics": ["sparse matrix"]}

{"title": "multi-modal obstacle detection in unstructured environments with conditional random fields", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "reliable obstacle detection and classification in rough and unstructured terrain such as agricultural fields or orchards remains a challenging problem"], ["INTRODUCTION", "these environments involve large variations in both geometry and appearance , challenging perception systems that rely on only a single sensor modality"], ["INTRODUCTION", "geometrically , tall grass , fallen leaves , or terrain roughness can mistakenly be perceived as non-traversable or might even obscure actual obstacles"], ["INTRODUCTION", "likewise , traversable grass or dirt roads and obstacles such as trees and bushes might be visually ambiguous"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we combine appearance- and geometry-based detection methods by probabilistically fusing lidar and camera sensing using a conditional random field"], ["BODY", "we apply a state-of-the-art multi-modal fusion algorithm from the scene analysis domain and adjust it for obstacle detection in agriculture with moving ground vehicles"], ["BODY", "this involves explicitly handling sparse point cloud data and exploiting both spatial , temporal , and multi-modal links between corresponding 2d and 3d regions"], ["CONCLUSION", "the proposed method is evaluated on a diverse dataset , comprising a dairy paddock and a number of different orchards gathered with a perception research robot in australia"], ["CONCLUSION", "results show that for a two-class classification problem ( ground and non-ground ) , only the camera leverages from information provided by the other modality"], ["CONCLUSION", "however , as more classes are introduced ( ground , sky , vegetation , and object ) , both modalities complement each other and improve the mean classification score"], ["CONCLUSION", "further improvement is achieved by introducing recursive inference with temporal links between successive frames ."]], "topics": ["sparse matrix"]}
{"title": "information-theoretic semi-supervised metric learning via entropy regularization", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose a general information-theoretic approach called seraph ( semi-supervised metric learning paradigm with hyper-sparsity ) for metric learning that does not rely upon the manifold assumption"], ["BODY", "given the probability parameterized by a mahalanobis distance , we maximize the entropy of that probability on labeled data and minimize it on unlabeled data following entropy regularization , which allows the supervised and unsupervised parts to be integrated in a natural and meaningful way"], ["BODY", "furthermore , seraph is regularized by encouraging a low-rank projection induced from the metric"], ["BODY", "the optimization of seraph is solved efficiently and stably by an em-like scheme with the analytical e-step and convex m-step"], ["CONCLUSION", "experiments demonstrate that seraph compares favorably with many well-known global and local metric learning methods ."]], "topics": ["optimization problem", "matrix regularization"]}
{"title": "efficient approximate solutions to mutual information based global feature selection", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "mutual information ( mi ) is often used for feature selection when developing classifier models"], ["INTRODUCTION", "estimating the mi for a subset of features is often intractable"], ["BODY", "we demonstrate , that under the assumptions of conditional independence , mi between a subset of features can be expressed as the conditional mutual information ( cmi ) between pairs of features"], ["BODY", "but selecting features with the highest cmi turns out to be a hard combinatorial problem"], ["BODY", "in this work , we have applied two unique global methods , truncated power method ( tpower ) and low rank bilinear approximation ( lowrank ) , to solve the feature selection problem"], ["BODY", "these algorithms provide very good approximations to the np-hard cmi based feature selection problem"], ["CONCLUSION", "we experimentally demonstrate the effectiveness of these procedures across multiple datasets and compare them with existing mi based global and iterative feature selection procedures ."]], "topics": ["approximation"]}
{"title": "enhanced local binary patterns for automatic face recognition", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "this paper presents a novel automatic face recognition approach based on local binary patterns ( lbp )"], ["BODY", "lbp descriptor considers a local neighbourhood of a pixel to compute the features"], ["BODY", "this method is not very robust to handle image noise , variances and different illumination conditions"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we address these issues and extend the original lbp operator by considering more pixels and different neighbourhoods to compute the feature vector"], ["BODY", "the proposed method is evaluated on two benchmark corpora , namely ufi and feret face datasets"], ["CONCLUSION", "we experimentally show that our approach is very efficient because it significantly outperforms several other state-of-the-art methods and is efficient particularly in the real conditions where the above mentioned issues are obvious ."]], "topics": ["feature vector", "text corpus"]}
{"title": "deepnorm-a deep learning approach to text normalization", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "this paper presents an simple yet sophisticated approach to the challenge by sproat and jaitly ( 2016 ) - given a large corpus of written text aligned to its normalized spoken form , train an rnn to learn the correct normalization function"], ["BODY", "text normalization for a token seems very straightforward without it 's context"], ["BODY", "but given the context of the used token and then normalizing becomes tricky for some classes"], ["BODY", "we present a novel approach in which the prediction of our classification algorithm is used by our sequence to sequence model to predict the normalized text of the input token"], ["CONCLUSION", "our approach takes very less time to learn and perform well unlike what has been reported by google ( 5 days on their gpu cluster )"], ["CONCLUSION", "we have achieved an accuracy of 97.62 which is impressive given the resources we use"], ["CONCLUSION", "our approach is using the best of both worlds , gradient boosting - state of the art in most classification tasks and sequence to sequence learning - state of the art in machine translation"], ["CONCLUSION", "we present our experiments and report results with various parameter settings ."]], "topics": ["machine translation", "gradient"]}
{"title": "anticipating visual representations from unlabeled video", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "anticipating actions and objects before they start or appear is a difficult problem in computer vision with several real-world applications"], ["INTRODUCTION", "this task is challenging partly because it requires leveraging extensive knowledge of the world that is difficult to write down"], ["INTRODUCTION", "we believe that a promising resource for efficiently learning this knowledge is through readily available unlabeled video"], ["BODY", "we present a framework that capitalizes on temporal structure in unlabeled video to learn to anticipate human actions and objects"], ["BODY", "the key idea behind our approach is that we can train deep networks to predict the visual representation of images in the future"], ["BODY", "visual representations are a promising prediction target because they encode images at a higher semantic level than pixels yet are automatic to compute"], ["BODY", "we then apply recognition algorithms on our predicted representation to anticipate objects and actions"], ["CONCLUSION", "we experimentally validate this idea on two datasets , anticipating actions one second in the future and objects five seconds in the future ."]], "topics": ["computer vision", "pixel"]}
{"title": "new advances in inference by recursive conditioning", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "recursive conditioning ( rc ) was introduced recently as the first any-space algorithm for inference in bayesian networks which can trade time for space by varying the size of its cache at the increment needed to store a floating point number"], ["INTRODUCTION", "under full caching , rc has an asymptotic time and space complexity which is comparable to mainstream algorithms based on variable elimination and clustering ( exponential in the network treewidth and linear in its size )"], ["BODY", "we show two main results about rc in this paper"], ["BODY", "first , we show that its actual space requirements under full caching are much more modest than those needed by mainstream methods and study the implications of this finding"], ["BODY", "second , we show that rc can effectively deal with determinism in bayesian networks by employing standard logical techniques , such as unit resolution , allowing a significant reduction in its time requirements in certain cases"], ["CONCLUSION", "we illustrate our results using a number of benchmark networks , including the very challenging ones that arise in genetic linkage analysis ."]], "topics": ["cluster analysis", "time complexity"]}
{"title": "action recognition with joint attention on multi-level deep features", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose a novel deep supervised neural network for the task of action recognition in videos , which implicitly takes advantage of visual tracking and shares the robustness of both deep convolutional neural network ( cnn ) and recurrent neural network ( rnn )"], ["BODY", "in our method , a multi-branch model is proposed to suppress noise from background jitters"], ["BODY", "specifically , we firstly extract multi-level deep features from deep cnns and feed them into 3d-convolutional network"], ["BODY", "after that we feed those feature cubes into our novel joint lstm module to predict labels and to generate attention regularization"], ["BODY", "we evaluate our model on two challenging datasets : ucf101 and hmdb51"], ["CONCLUSION", "the results show that our model achieves the state-of-art by only using convolutional features ."]], "topics": ["recurrent neural network", "matrix regularization"]}
{"title": "a correlation game for unsupervised learning yields computational interpretations of hebbian excitation , anti-hebbian inhibition , and synapse elimination", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "much has been learned about plasticity of biological synapses from empirical studies"], ["INTRODUCTION", "hebbian plasticity is driven by correlated activity of presynaptic and postsynaptic neurons"], ["INTRODUCTION", "synapses that converge onto the same neuron often behave as if they compete for a fixed resource ; some survive the competition while others are eliminated"], ["BODY", "to provide computational interpretations of these aspects of synaptic plasticity , we formulate unsupervised learning as a zero-sum game between hebbian excitation and anti-hebbian inhibition in a neural network model"], ["BODY", "the game formalizes the intuition that hebbian excitation tries to maximize correlations of neurons with their inputs , while anti-hebbian inhibition tries to decorrelate neurons from each other"], ["BODY", "we further include a model of synaptic competition , which enables a neuron to eliminate all connections except those from its most strongly correlated inputs"], ["CONCLUSION", "through empirical studies , we show that this facilitates the learning of sensory features that resemble parts of objects ."]], "topics": ["feature learning", "unsupervised learning"]}
{"title": "very efficient training of convolutional neural networks using fast fourier transform and overlap-and-add", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "convolutional neural networks ( cnns ) are currently state-of-the-art for various classification tasks , but are computationally expensive"], ["INTRODUCTION", "propagating through the convolutional layers is very slow , as each kernel in each layer must sequentially calculate many dot products for a single forward and backward propagation which equates to $ \\mathcal { o } ( n^ { 2 } n^ { 2 } ) $ per kernel per layer where the inputs are $ n \\times n $ arrays and the kernels are $ n \\times n $ arrays"], ["INTRODUCTION", "convolution can be efficiently performed as a hadamard product in the frequency domain"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the bottleneck is the transformation which has a cost of $ \\mathcal { o } ( n^ { 2 } \\log_2 n ) $ using the fast fourier transform ( fft )"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , the increase in efficiency is less significant when $ n\\gg n $ as is the case in cnns"], ["BODY", "we mitigate this by using the `` overlap-and-add '' technique reducing the computational complexity to $ \\mathcal { o } ( n^2\\log_2 n ) $ per kernel"], ["BODY", "this method increases the algorithm 's efficiency in both the forward and backward propagation , reducing the training and testing time for cnns"], ["CONCLUSION", "our empirical results show our method reduces computational time by a factor of up to 16.3 times the traditional convolution implementation for a 8 $ \\times $ 8 kernel and a 224 $ \\times $ 224 image ."]], "topics": ["kernel ( operating system )", "time complexity"]}

{"title": "noisy networks for exploration", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we introduce noisynet , a deep reinforcement learning agent with parametric noise added to its weights , and show that the induced stochasticity of the agent 's policy can be used to aid efficient exploration"], ["BODY", "the parameters of the noise are learned with gradient descent along with the remaining network weights"], ["BODY", "noisynet is straightforward to implement and adds little computational overhead"], ["CONCLUSION", "we find that replacing the conventional exploration heuristics for a3c , dqn and dueling agents ( entropy reward and $ \\epsilon $ -greedy respectively ) with noisynet yields substantially higher scores for a wide range of atari games , in some cases advancing the agent from sub to super-human performance ."]], "topics": ["reinforcement learning", "gradient descent"]}
{"title": "unsupervised learning of regression mixture models with unknown number of components", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "regression mixture models are widely studied in statistics , machine learning and data analysis"], ["INTRODUCTION", "fitting regression mixtures is challenging and is usually performed by maximum likelihood by using the expectation-maximization ( em ) algorithm"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , it is well-known that the initialization is crucial for em"], ["INTRODUCTION", "if the initialization is inappropriately performed , the em algorithm may lead to unsatisfactory results"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the em algorithm also requires the number of clusters to be given a priori ; the problem of selecting the number of mixture components requires using model selection criteria to choose one from a set of pre-estimated candidate models"], ["BODY", "we propose a new fully unsupervised algorithm to learn regression mixture models with unknown number of components"], ["BODY", "the developed unsupervised learning approach consists in a penalized maximum likelihood estimation carried out by a robust expectation-maximization ( em ) algorithm for fitting polynomial , spline and b-spline regressions mixtures"], ["BODY", "the proposed learning approach is fully unsupervised : 1 ) it simultaneously infers the model parameters and the optimal number of the regression mixture components from the data as the learning proceeds , rather than in a two-fold scheme as in standard model-based clustering using afterward model selection criteria , and 2 ) it does not require accurate initialization unlike the standard em for regression mixtures"], ["BODY", "the developed approach is applied to curve clustering problems"], ["CONCLUSION", "numerical experiments on simulated data show that the proposed robust em algorithm performs well and provides accurate results in terms of robustness with regard initialization and retrieving the optimal partition with the actual number of clusters"], ["CONCLUSION", "an application to real data in the framework of functional data clustering , confirms the benefit of the proposed approach for practical applications ."]], "topics": ["cluster analysis", "unsupervised learning"]}
{"title": "superspike : supervised learning in multi-layer spiking neural networks", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "a vast majority of computation in the brain is performed by spiking neural networks"], ["INTRODUCTION", "despite the ubiquity of such spiking , we currently lack an understanding of how biological spiking neural circuits learn and compute in-vivo , as well as how we can instantiate such capabilities in artificial spiking circuits in-silico"], ["BODY", "here we revisit the problem of supervised learning in temporally coding multi-layer spiking neural networks"], ["BODY", "first , by using a surrogate gradient approach , we derive superspike , a nonlinear voltage-based three factor learning rule capable of training multi-layer networks of deterministic integrate-and-fire neurons to perform nonlinear computations on spatiotemporal spike patterns"], ["BODY", "second , inspired by recent results on feedback alignment , we compare the performance of our learning rule under different credit assignment strategies for propagating output errors to hidden units"], ["BODY", "specifically , we test uniform , symmetric and random feedback , finding that simpler tasks can be solved with any type of feedback , while more complex tasks require symmetric feedback"], ["CONCLUSION", "in summary , our results open the door to obtaining a better scientific understanding of learning and computation in spiking neural networks by advancing our ability to train them to solve nonlinear problems involving transformations between different spatiotemporal spike-time patterns ."]], "topics": ["supervised learning", "nonlinear system"]}

{"title": "random multi-constraint projection : stochastic gradient methods for convex optimization with many constraints", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "consider convex optimization problems subject to a large number of constraints"], ["BODY", "we focus on stochastic problems in which the objective takes the form of expected values and the feasible set is the intersection of a large number of convex sets"], ["BODY", "we propose a class of algorithms that perform both stochastic gradient descent and random feasibility updates simultaneously"], ["BODY", "at every iteration , the algorithms sample a number of projection points onto a randomly selected small subsets of all constraints"], ["BODY", "three feasibility update schemes are considered : averaging over random projected points , projecting onto the most distant sample , projecting onto a special polyhedral set constructed based on sample points"], ["CONCLUSION", "we prove the almost sure convergence of these algorithms , and analyze the iterates ' feasibility error and optimality error , respectively"], ["CONCLUSION", "we provide new convergence rate benchmarks for stochastic first-order optimization with many constraints"], ["CONCLUSION", "the rate analysis and numerical experiments reveal that the algorithm using the polyhedral-set projection scheme is the most efficient one within known algorithms ."]], "topics": ["value ( ethics )", "numerical analysis"]}
