{"title": "applying aco to large scale tsp instances", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "ant colony optimisation ( aco ) is a well known metaheuristic that has proven successful at solving travelling salesman problems ( tsp )"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , aco suffers from two issues ; the first is that the technique has significant memory requirements for storing pheromone levels on edges between cities and second , the iterative probabilistic nature of choosing which city to visit next at every step is computationally expensive"], ["INTRODUCTION", "this restricts aco from solving larger tsp instances"], ["BODY", "this paper will present a methodology for deploying aco on larger tsp instances by removing the high memory requirements , exploiting parallel cpu hardware and introducing a significant efficiency saving measure"], ["BODY", "the approach results in greater accuracy and speed"], ["CONCLUSION", "this enables the proposed aco approach to tackle tsp instances of up to 200k cities within reasonable timescales using a single cpu"], ["CONCLUSION", "speedups of as much as 1200 fold are achieved by the technique ."]], "topics": ["iteration"]}
{"title": "evidential relational clustering using medoids", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in real clustering applications , proximity data , in which only pairwise similarities or dissimilarities are known , is more general than object data , in which each pattern is described explicitly by a list of attributes"], ["INTRODUCTION", "medoid-based clustering algorithms , which assume the prototypes of classes are objects , are of great value for partitioning relational data sets"], ["BODY", "in this paper a new prototype-based clustering method , named evidential c-medoids ( ecmdd ) , which is an extension of fuzzy c-medoids ( fcmdd ) on the theoretical framework of belief functions is proposed"], ["BODY", "in ecmdd , medoids are utilized as the prototypes to represent the detected classes , including specific classes and imprecise classes"], ["BODY", "specific classes are for the data which are distinctly far from the prototypes of other classes , while imprecise classes accept the objects that may be close to the prototypes of more than one class"], ["BODY", "this soft decision mechanism could make the clustering results more cautious and reduce the misclassification rates"], ["CONCLUSION", "experiments in synthetic and real data sets are used to illustrate the performance of ecmdd"], ["CONCLUSION", "the results show that ecmdd could capture well the uncertainty in the internal data structure"], ["CONCLUSION", "moreover , it is more robust to the initializations compared with fcmdd ."]], "topics": ["cluster analysis", "synthetic data"]}
{"title": "liuboost : locality informed underboosting for imbalanced data classification", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the problem of class imbalance along with class-overlapping has become a major issue in the domain of supervised learning"], ["INTRODUCTION", "most supervised learning algorithms assume equal cardinality of the classes under consideration while optimizing the cost function and this assumption does not hold true for imbalanced datasets which results in sub-optimal classification"], ["BODY", "therefore , various approaches , such as undersampling , oversampling , cost-sensitive learning and ensemble based methods have been proposed for dealing with imbalanced datasets"], ["BODY", "however , undersampling suffers from information loss , oversampling suffers from increased runtime and potential overfitting while cost-sensitive methods suffer due to inadequately defined cost assignment schemes"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we propose a novel boosting based method called liuboost"], ["BODY", "liuboost uses under sampling for balancing the datasets in every boosting iteration like rusboost while incorporating a cost term for every instance based on their hardness into the weight update formula minimizing the information loss introduced by undersampling"], ["CONCLUSION", "liuboost has been extensively evaluated on 18 imbalanced datasets and the results indicate significant improvement over existing best performing method rusboost ."]], "topics": ["supervised learning", "loss function"]}

{"title": "incorporating type ii error probabilities from independence tests into score-based learning of bayesian network structure", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we give a new consistent scoring function for structure learning of bayesian networks"], ["BODY", "in contrast to traditional approaches to score-based structure learning , such as bdeu or mdl , the complexity penalty that we propose is data-dependent and is given by the probability that a conditional independence test correctly shows that an edge can not exist"], ["BODY", "what really distinguishes this new scoring function from earlier work is that it has the property of becoming computationally easier to maximize as the amount of data increases"], ["BODY", "we prove a polynomial sample complexity result , showing that maximizing this score is guaranteed to correctly learn a structure with no false edges and a distribution close to the generating distribution , whenever there exists a bayesian network which is a perfect map for the data generating distribution"], ["CONCLUSION", "although the new score can be used with any search algorithm , in our related uai 2013 paper [ bs13 ] , we have given empirical results showing that it is particularly effective when used together with a linear programming relaxation approach to bayesian network structure learning"], ["CONCLUSION", "the present paper contains all details of the proofs of the finite-sample complexity results in [ bs13 ] as well as detailed explanation of the computation of the certain error probabilities called beta-values , whose precomputation and tabulation is necessary for the implementation of the algorithm in [ bs13 ] ."]], "topics": ["time complexity", "computation"]}
{"title": "camera calibration for daylight specular-point locus", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in this paper we present a new camera calibration method aimed at finding a straight-line locus , in a special colour feature space , that is traversed by daylights and as well also approximately followed by specular points"], ["BODY", "the aim of the calibration is to enable recovering the colour of the illuminant in a scene , using the calibrated camera"], ["BODY", "first we prove theoretically that any candidate specular points , for an image that is generated by a specific camera and taken under a daylight , must lie on a straight line in log-chromaticity space , for a chromaticity that is generated using a geometric-mean denominator"], ["BODY", "use is made of the assumptions that daylight illuminants can be approximated using planckians and that camera sensors are narrowband or can be made so by spectral sharpening"], ["BODY", "then we show how a particular camera can be calibrated so as to discover this locus"], ["CONCLUSION", "as applications we use this curve for illuminant detection , and also for re-lighting of images to show they would appear under lighting having a different colour temperature ."]], "topics": ["feature vector", "sensor"]}
{"title": "high dimensional bayesian optimisation and bandits via additive models", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "bayesian optimisation ( bo ) is a technique used in optimising a $ d $ -dimensional function which is typically expensive to evaluate"], ["INTRODUCTION", "while there have been many successes for bo in low dimensions , scaling it to high dimensions has been notoriously difficult"], ["INTRODUCTION", "existing literature on the topic are under very restrictive settings"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we identify two key challenges in this endeavour"], ["BODY", "we tackle these challenges by assuming an additive structure for the function"], ["BODY", "this setting is substantially more expressive and contains a richer class of functions than previous work"], ["CONCLUSION", "we prove that , for additive functions the regret has only linear dependence on $ d $ even though the function depends on all $ d $ dimensions"], ["CONCLUSION", "we also demonstrate several other statistical and computational benefits in our framework"], ["CONCLUSION", "via synthetic examples , a scientific simulation and a face detection problem we demonstrate that our method outperforms naive bo on additive functions and on several examples where the function is not additive ."]], "topics": ["regret ( decision theory )", "mathematical optimization"]}
{"title": "restricted boltzmann machines for robust and fast latent truth discovery", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we address the problem of latent truth discovery , ltd for short , where the goal is to discover the underlying true values of entity attributes in the presence of noisy , conflicting or incomplete information"], ["BODY", "despite a multitude of algorithms to address the ltd problem that can be found in literature , only little is known about their overall performance with respect to effectiveness ( in terms of truth discovery capabilities ) , efficiency and robustness"], ["BODY", "a practical ltd approach should satisfy all these characteristics so that it can be applied to heterogeneous datasets of varying quality and degrees of cleanliness"], ["BODY", "we propose a novel algorithm for ltd that satisfies the above requirements"], ["BODY", "the proposed model is based on restricted boltzmann machines , thus coined ltd-rbm"], ["CONCLUSION", "in extensive experiments on various heterogeneous and publicly available datasets , ltd-rbm is superior to state-of-the-art ltd techniques in terms of an overall consideration of effectiveness , efficiency and robustness ."]], "topics": ["value ( ethics )"]}
{"title": "positive semidefinite metric learning with boosting", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the learning of appropriate distance metrics is a critical problem in image classification and retrieval"], ["BODY", "in this work , we propose a boosting-based technique , termed \\boostmetric , for learning a mahalanobis distance metric"], ["BODY", "one of the primary difficulties in learning such a metric is to ensure that the mahalanobis matrix remains positive semidefinite"], ["BODY", "semidefinite programming is sometimes used to enforce this constraint , but does not scale well"], ["BODY", "\\boostmetric is instead based on a key observation that any positive semidefinite matrix can be decomposed into a linear positive combination of trace-one rank-one matrices"], ["BODY", "\\boostmetric thus uses rank-one positive semidefinite matrices as weak learners within an efficient and scalable boosting-based learning process"], ["BODY", "the resulting method is easy to implement , does not require tuning , and can accommodate various types of constraints"], ["CONCLUSION", "experiments on various datasets show that the proposed algorithm compares favorably to those state-of-the-art methods in terms of classification accuracy and running time ."]], "topics": ["time complexity", "computer vision"]}
{"title": "squeezedet : unified , small , low power fully convolutional neural networks for real-time object detection for autonomous driving", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "object detection is a crucial task for autonomous driving"], ["INTRODUCTION", "in addition to requiring high accuracy to ensure safety , object detection for autonomous driving also requires real-time inference speed to guarantee prompt vehicle control , as well as small model size and energy efficiency to enable embedded system deployment"], ["BODY", "in this work , we propose squeezedet , a fully convolutional neural network for object detection that aims to simultaneously satisfy all of the above constraints"], ["BODY", "in our network we use convolutional layers not only to extract feature maps , but also as the output layer to compute bounding boxes and class probabilities"], ["BODY", "the detection pipeline of our model only contains a single forward pass of a neural network , thus it is extremely fast"], ["BODY", "our model is fully-convolutional , which leads to small model size and better energy efficiency"], ["CONCLUSION", "finally , our experiments show that our model is very accurate , achieving state-of-the-art accuracy on the kitti benchmark ."]], "topics": ["object detection", "map"]}
{"title": "a convex approach for image hallucination", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in this paper we propose a global convex approach for image hallucination"], ["BODY", "altering the idea of classical multi image super resolution ( su ) systems to single image su , we incorporate aligned images to hallucinate the output"], ["BODY", "our work is based on the paper of tappen et al"], ["BODY", "where they use a non-convex model for image hallucination"], ["BODY", "in comparison we formulate a convex primal optimization problem and derive a fast converging primal-dual algorithm with a global optimal solution"], ["BODY", "we use a database with face images to incorporate high-frequency details to the high-resolution output"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show that we can achieve state-of-the-art results by using a convex approach ."]], "topics": ["optimization problem"]}
{"title": "data sets : word embeddings learned from tweets and general data", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "a word embedding is a low-dimensional , dense and real- valued vector representation of a word"], ["INTRODUCTION", "word embeddings have been used in many nlp tasks"], ["INTRODUCTION", "they are usually gener- ated from a large text corpus"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the embedding of a word cap- tures both its syntactic and semantic aspects"], ["INTRODUCTION", "tweets are short , noisy and have unique lexical and semantic features that are different from other types of text"], ["INTRODUCTION", "therefore , it is necessary to have word embeddings learned specifically from tweets"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we present ten word embedding data sets"], ["BODY", "in addition to the data sets learned from just tweet data , we also built embedding sets from the general data and the combination of tweets with the general data"], ["BODY", "the general data consist of news articles , wikipedia data and other web data"], ["CONCLUSION", "these ten embedding models were learned from about 400 million tweets and 7 billion words from the general text"], ["CONCLUSION", "in this paper , we also present two experiments demonstrating how to use the data sets in some nlp tasks , such as tweet sentiment analysis and tweet topic classification tasks ."]], "topics": ["natural language processing", "text corpus"]}
{"title": "attention-based end-to-end speech recognition on voice search", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "recently , there has been a growing interest in end-to-end speech recognition that directly transcribes speech to text without any predefined alignments"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we explore the use of attention-based encoder-decoder model for mandarin speech recognition on a voice search task"], ["BODY", "previous attempts have shown that applying attention-based encoder-decoder to mandarin speech recognition was quite difficult due to the logographic orthography of mandarin , the large vocabulary and the conditional dependency of the attention model"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we use character embedding to deal with the large vocabulary"], ["BODY", "several tricks are used for effective model training , including l2 regularization , gaussian weight noise and frame skipping"], ["BODY", "we compare two attention mechanisms and use attention smoothing to cover long context in the attention model"], ["CONCLUSION", "taken together , these tricks allow us to finally achieve a character error rate ( cer ) of 3.58 % and a sentence error rate ( ser ) of 7.43 % on the mitv voice search dataset"], ["CONCLUSION", "while together with a trigram language model , cer and ser reach 2.81 % and 5.77 % , respectively ."]], "topics": ["speech recognition", "speech recognition"]}
{"title": "blind system identification using kernel-based methods", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose a new method for blind system identification"], ["BODY", "resorting to a gaussian regression framework , we model the impulse response of the unknown linear system as a realization of a gaussian process"], ["BODY", "the structure of the covariance matrix ( or kernel ) of such a process is given by the stable spline kernel , which has been recently introduced for system identification purposes and depends on an unknown hyperparameter"], ["BODY", "we assume that the input can be linearly described by few parameters"], ["BODY", "we estimate these parameters , together with the kernel hyperparameter and the noise variance , using an empirical bayes approach"], ["BODY", "the related optimization problem is efficiently solved with a novel iterative scheme based on the expectation-maximization method"], ["CONCLUSION", "in particular , we show that each iteration consists of a set of simple update rules"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show , through some numerical experiments , very promising performance of the proposed method ."]], "topics": ["kernel ( operating system )", "optimization problem"]}

{"title": "one sense per collocation and genre/topic variations", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "this paper revisits the one sense per collocation hypothesis using fine-grained sense distinctions and two different corpora"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show that the hypothesis is weaker for fine-grained sense distinctions ( 70 % vs. 99 % reported earlier on 2-way ambiguities )"], ["CONCLUSION", "we also show that one sense per collocation does hold across corpora , but that collocations vary from one corpus to the other , following genre and topic variations"], ["CONCLUSION", "this explains the low results when performing word sense disambiguation across corpora"], ["CONCLUSION", "in fact , we demonstrate that when two independent corpora share a related genre/topic , the word sense disambiguation results would be better"], ["CONCLUSION", "future work on word sense disambiguation will have to take into account genre and topic as important parameters on their models ."]], "topics": ["text corpus"]}
{"title": "to drop or not to drop : robustness , consistency and differential privacy properties of dropout", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "training deep belief networks ( dbns ) requires optimizing a non-convex function with an extremely large number of parameters"], ["INTRODUCTION", "naturally , existing gradient descent ( gd ) based methods are prone to arbitrarily poor local minima"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we rigorously show that such local minima can be avoided ( upto an approximation error ) by using the dropout technique , a widely used heuristic in this domain"], ["BODY", "in particular , we show that by randomly dropping a few nodes of a one-hidden layer neural network , the training objective function , up to a certain approximation error , decreases by a multiplicative factor"], ["BODY", "on the flip side , we show that for training convex empirical risk minimizers ( erm ) , dropout in fact acts as a `` stabilizer '' or regularizer"], ["BODY", "that is , a simple dropout based gd method for convex erms is stable in the face of arbitrary changes to any one of the training points"], ["CONCLUSION", "using the above assertion , we show that dropout provides fast rates for generalization error in learning ( convex ) generalized linear models ( glm )"], ["CONCLUSION", "moreover , using the above mentioned stability properties of dropout , we design dropout based differentially private algorithms for solving erms"], ["CONCLUSION", "the learned glm thus , preserves privacy of each of the individual training points while providing accurate predictions for new test points"], ["CONCLUSION", "finally , we empirically validate our stability assertions for dropout in the context of convex erms and show that surprisingly , dropout significantly outperforms ( in terms of prediction accuracy ) the l2 regularization based methods for several benchmark datasets ."]], "topics": ["loss function", "matrix regularization"]}
{"title": "multiple output regression with latent noise", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in high-dimensional data , structured noise caused by observed and unobserved factors affecting multiple target variables simultaneously , imposes a serious challenge for modeling , by masking the often weak signal"], ["INTRODUCTION", "therefore , ( 1 ) explaining away the structured noise in multiple-output regression is of paramount importance"], ["INTRODUCTION", "additionally , ( 2 ) assumptions about the correlation structure of the regression weights are needed"], ["BODY", "we note that both can be formulated in a natural way in a latent variable model , in which both the interesting signal and the noise are mediated through the same latent factors"], ["BODY", "under this assumption , the signal model then borrows strength from the noise model by encouraging similar effects on correlated targets"], ["BODY", "we introduce a hyperparameter for the \\emph { latent signal-to-noise ratio } which turns out to be important for modelling weak signals , and an ordered infinite-dimensional shrinkage prior that resolves the rotational unidentifiability in reduced-rank regression models"], ["CONCLUSION", "simulations and prediction experiments with metabolite , gene expression , fmri measurement , and macroeconomic time series data show that our model equals or exceeds the state-of-the-art performance and , in particular , outperforms the standard approach of assuming independent noise and signal models ."]], "topics": ["time series"]}
{"title": "semi-supervised question retrieval with gated convolutions", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "question answering forums are rapidly growing in size with no effective automated ability to refer to and reuse answers already available for previous posted questions"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we develop a methodology for finding semantically related questions"], ["BODY", "the task is difficult since 1 ) key pieces of information are often buried in extraneous details in the question body and 2 ) available annotations on similar questions are scarce and fragmented"], ["BODY", "we design a recurrent and convolutional model ( gated convolution ) to effectively map questions to their semantic representations"], ["BODY", "the models are pre-trained within an encoder-decoder framework ( from body to title ) on the basis of the entire raw corpus , and fine-tuned discriminatively from limited annotations"], ["CONCLUSION", "our evaluation demonstrates that our model yields substantial gains over a standard ir baseline and various neural network architectures ( including cnns , lstms and grus ) ."]], "topics": ["baseline ( configuration management )", "recurrent neural network"]}
{"title": "partial reinitialisation for optimisers", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "heuristic optimisers which search for an optimal configuration of variables relative to an objective function often get stuck in local optima where the algorithm is unable to find further improvement"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the standard approach to circumvent this problem involves periodically restarting the algorithm from random initial configurations when no further improvement can be found"], ["BODY", "we propose a method of partial reinitialization , whereby , in an attempt to find a better solution , only sub-sets of variables are re-initialised rather than the whole configuration"], ["BODY", "much of the information gained from previous runs is hence retained"], ["CONCLUSION", "this leads to significant improvements in the quality of the solution found in a given time for a variety of optimisation problems in machine learning ."]], "topics": ["mathematical optimization", "loss function"]}

{"title": "near-optimal algorithms for differentially-private principal components", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "principal components analysis ( pca ) is a standard tool for identifying good low-dimensional approximations to data in high dimension"], ["INTRODUCTION", "many data sets of interest contain private or sensitive information about individuals"], ["INTRODUCTION", "algorithms which operate on such data should be sensitive to the privacy risks in publishing their outputs"], ["INTRODUCTION", "differential privacy is a framework for developing tradeoffs between privacy and the utility of these outputs"], ["BODY", "in this paper we investigate the theory and empirical performance of differentially private approximations to pca and propose a new method which explicitly optimizes the utility of the output"], ["BODY", "we show that the sample complexity of the proposed method differs from the existing procedure in the scaling with the data dimension , and that our method is nearly optimal in terms of this scaling"], ["CONCLUSION", "we furthermore illustrate our results , showing that on real data there is a large performance gap between the existing method and our method ."]], "topics": ["approximation"]}
{"title": "rail : risk-averse imitation learning", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "imitation learning algorithms learn viable policies by imitating an expert 's behavior when reward signals are not available"], ["INTRODUCTION", "generative adversarial imitation learning ( gail ) is a state-of-the-art algorithm for learning policies when the expert 's behavior is available as a fixed set of trajectories"], ["BODY", "we evaluate in terms of the expert 's cost function and observe that the distribution of trajectory-costs is often more heavy-tailed for gail-agents than the expert at a number of benchmark continuous-control tasks"], ["BODY", "thus , high-cost trajectories , corresponding to tail-end events of catastrophic failure , are more likely to be encountered by the gail-agents than the expert"], ["BODY", "this makes the reliability of gail-agents questionable when it comes to deployment in risk-sensitive applications like robotic surgery and autonomous driving"], ["CONCLUSION", "in this work , we aim to minimize the occurrence of tail-end events by minimizing tail risk within the gail framework"], ["CONCLUSION", "we quantify tail risk by the conditional-value-at-risk ( cvar ) of trajectories and develop the risk-averse imitation learning ( rail ) algorithm"], ["CONCLUSION", "we observe that the policies learned with rail show lower tail-end risk than those of vanilla gail"], ["CONCLUSION", "thus the proposed rail algorithm appears as a potent alternative to gail for improved reliability in risk-sensitive applications ."]], "topics": ["loss function", "autonomous car"]}

{"title": "exploiting generalisation symmetries in accuracy-based learning classifier systems : an initial study", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "modern learning classifier systems typically exploit a niched genetic algorithm to facilitate rule discovery"], ["INTRODUCTION", "when used for reinforcement learning , such rules represent generalisations over the state-action-reward space"], ["INTRODUCTION", "whilst encouraging maximal generality , the niching can potentially hinder the formation of generalisations in the state space which are symmetrical , or very similar , over different actions"], ["BODY", "this paper introduces the use of rules which contain multiple actions , maintaining accuracy and reward metrics for each action"], ["CONCLUSION", "it is shown that problem symmetries can be exploited , improving performance , whilst not degrading performance when symmetries are reduced ."]], "topics": ["reinforcement learning"]}

{"title": "sesa : supervised explicit semantic analysis", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in recent years supervised representation learning has provided state of the art or close to the state of the art results in semantic analysis tasks including ranking and information retrieval"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the core idea is to learn how to embed items into a latent space such that they optimize a supervised objective in that latent space"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the dimensions of the latent space have no clear semantics , and this reduces the interpretability of the system"], ["INTRODUCTION", "for example , in personalization models , it is hard to explain why a particular item is ranked high for a given user profile"], ["BODY", "we propose a novel model of representation learning called supervised explicit semantic analysis ( sesa ) that is trained in a supervised fashion to embed items to a set of dimensions with explicit semantics"], ["BODY", "the model learns to compare two objects by representing them in this explicit space , where each dimension corresponds to a concept from a knowledge base"], ["BODY", "this work extends explicit semantic analysis ( esa ) with a supervised model for ranking problems"], ["BODY", "we apply this model to the task of job-profile relevance in linkedin in which a set of skills defines our explicit dimensions of the space"], ["BODY", "every profile and job are encoded to this set of skills their similarity is calculated in this space"], ["BODY", "we use rnns to embed text input into this space"], ["BODY", "in addition to interpretability , our model makes use of the web-scale collaborative skills data that is provided by users for each linkedin profile"], ["CONCLUSION", "our model provides state of the art result while it remains interpretable ."]], "topics": ["feature learning", "relevance"]}
{"title": "hamsi : a parallel incremental optimization algorithm using quadratic approximations for solving partially separable problems", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose hamsi ( hessian approximated multiple subsets iteration ) , which is a provably convergent , second order incremental algorithm for solving large-scale partially separable optimization problems"], ["BODY", "the algorithm is based on a local quadratic approximation , and hence , allows incorporating curvature information to speed-up the convergence"], ["BODY", "hamsi is inherently parallel and it scales nicely with the number of processors"], ["BODY", "combined with techniques for effectively utilizing modern parallel computer architectures , we illustrate that the proposed method converges more rapidly than a parallel stochastic gradient descent when both methods are used to solve large-scale matrix factorization problems"], ["BODY", "this performance gain comes only at the expense of using memory that scales linearly with the total size of the optimization variables"], ["CONCLUSION", "we conclude that hamsi may be considered as a viable alternative in many large scale problems , where first order methods based on variants of stochastic gradient descent are applicable ."]], "topics": ["mathematical optimization", "gradient descent"]}

{"title": "from source to target and back : symmetric bi-directional adaptive gan", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the effectiveness of generative adversarial approaches in producing images according to a specific style or visual domain has recently opened new directions to solve the unsupervised domain adaptation problem"], ["INTRODUCTION", "it has been shown that source labeled images can be modified to mimic target samples making it possible to train directly a classifier in the target domain , despite the original lack of annotated data"], ["INTRODUCTION", "inverse mappings from the target to the source domain have also been evaluated but only passing through adapted feature spaces , thus without new image generation"], ["BODY", "in this paper we propose to better exploit the potential of generative adversarial networks for adaptation by introducing a novel symmetric mapping among domains"], ["BODY", "we jointly optimize bi-directional image transformations combining them with target self-labeling"], ["BODY", "moreover we define a new class consistency loss that aligns the generators in the two directions imposing to conserve the class identity of an image passing through both domain mappings"], ["CONCLUSION", "a detailed qualitative and quantitative analysis of the reconstructed images confirm the power of our approach"], ["CONCLUSION", "by integrating the two domain specific classifiers obtained with our bi-directional network we exceed previous state-of-the-art unsupervised adaptation results on four different benchmark datasets ."]], "topics": ["statistical classification", "unsupervised learning"]}
{"title": "a compact avlsi conductance-based silicon neuron", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we present an analogue very large scale integration ( avlsi ) implementation that uses first-order lowpass filters to implement a conductance-based silicon neuron for high-speed neuromorphic systems"], ["BODY", "the avlsi neuron consists of a soma ( cell body ) and a single synapse , which is capable of linearly summing both the excitatory and inhibitory postsynaptic potentials ( epsp and ipsp ) generated by the spikes arriving from different sources"], ["BODY", "rather than biasing the silicon neuron with different parameters for different spiking patterns , as is typically done , we provide digital control signals , generated by an fpga , to the silicon neuron to obtain different spiking behaviours"], ["BODY", "the proposed neuron is only ~26.5 um2 in the ibm 130nm process and thus can be integrated at very high density"], ["CONCLUSION", "circuit simulations show that this neuron can emulate different spiking behaviours observed in biological neurons ."]], "topics": ["simulation"]}
{"title": "multi-atlas segmentation using partially annotated data : methods and annotation strategies", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "multi-atlas segmentation is a widely used tool in medical image analysis , providing robust and accurate results by learning from annotated atlas datasets"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , the availability of fully annotated atlas images for training is limited due to the time required for the labelling task"], ["INTRODUCTION", "segmentation methods requiring only a proportion of each atlas image to be labelled could therefore reduce the workload on expert raters tasked with annotating atlas images"], ["BODY", "to address this issue , we first re-examine the labelling problem common in many existing approaches and formulate its solution in terms of a markov random field energy minimisation problem on a graph connecting atlases and the target image"], ["BODY", "this provides a unifying framework for multi-atlas segmentation"], ["BODY", "we then show how modifications in the graph configuration of the proposed framework enable the use of partially annotated atlas images and investigate different partial annotation strategies"], ["CONCLUSION", "the proposed method was evaluated on two magnetic resonance imaging ( mri ) datasets for hippocampal and cardiac segmentation"], ["CONCLUSION", "experiments were performed aimed at ( 1 ) recreating existing segmentation techniques with the proposed framework and ( 2 ) demonstrating the potential of employing sparsely annotated atlas data for multi-atlas segmentation ."]], "topics": ["markov chain"]}
{"title": "reviving and improving recurrent back-propagation", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in this paper , we revisit the recurrent back-propagation ( rbp ) algorithm , discuss the conditions under which it applies as well as how to satisfy them in deep neural networks"], ["BODY", "we show that rbp can be unstable and propose two variants based on conjugate gradient on the normal equations ( cg-rbp ) and neumann series ( neumann-rbp )"], ["BODY", "we further investigate the relationship between neumann-rbp and back propagation through time ( bptt ) and its truncated version ( tbptt )"], ["BODY", "our neumann-rbp has the same time complexity as tbptt but only requires constant memory , whereas tbptt 's memory cost scales linearly with the number of truncation steps"], ["CONCLUSION", "we examine all rbp variants along with bptt and tbptt in three different application domains : associative memory with continuous hopfield networks , document classification in citation networks using graph neural networks and hyperparameter optimization for fully connected networks"], ["CONCLUSION", "all experiments demonstrate that rbps , especially the neumann-rbp variant , are efficient and effective for optimizing convergent recurrent neural networks ."]], "topics": ["recurrent neural network", "time complexity"]}
{"title": "l1-norm batch normalization for efficient training of deep neural networks", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "batch normalization ( bn ) has been proven to be quite effective at accelerating and improving the training of deep neural networks ( dnns )"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , bn brings additional computation , consumes more memory and generally slows down the training process by a large margin , which aggravates the training effort"], ["INTRODUCTION", "furthermore , the nonlinear square and root operations in bn also impede the low bit-width quantization techniques , which draws much attention in deep learning hardware community"], ["BODY", "in this work , we propose an l1-norm bn ( l1bn ) with only linear operations in both the forward and the backward propagations during training"], ["BODY", "l1bn is shown to be approximately equivalent to the original l2-norm bn ( l2bn ) by multiplying a scaling factor"], ["CONCLUSION", "experiments on various convolutional neural networks ( cnns ) and generative adversarial networks ( gans ) reveal that l1bn maintains almost the same accuracies and convergence rates compared to l2bn but with higher computational efficiency"], ["CONCLUSION", "on fpga platform , the proposed signum and absolute operations in l1bn can achieve 1.5 $ \\times $ speedup and save 50\\ % power consumption , compared with the original costly square and root operations , respectively"], ["CONCLUSION", "this hardware-friendly normalization method not only surpasses l2bn in speed , but also simplify the hardware design of asic accelerators with higher energy efficiency"], ["CONCLUSION", "last but not the least , l1bn promises a fully quantized training of dnns , which is crucial to future adaptive terminal devices ."]], "topics": ["nonlinear system", "computation"]}
{"title": "partial-hessian strategies for fast learning of nonlinear embeddings", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "stochastic neighbor embedding ( sne ) and related nonlinear manifold learning algorithms achieve high-quality low-dimensional representations of similarity data , but are notoriously slow to train"], ["BODY", "we propose a generic formulation of embedding algorithms that includes sne and other existing algorithms , and study their relation with spectral methods and graph laplacians"], ["BODY", "this allows us to define several partial-hessian optimization strategies , characterize their global and local convergence , and evaluate them empirically"], ["CONCLUSION", "we achieve up to two orders of magnitude speedup over existing training methods with a strategy ( which we call the spectral direction ) that adds nearly no overhead to the gradient and yet is simple , scalable and applicable to several existing and future embedding algorithms ."]], "topics": ["nonlinear system", "scalability"]}
{"title": "image classification using local tensor singular value decompositions", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "from linear classifiers to neural networks , image classification has been a widely explored topic in mathematics , and many algorithms have proven to be effective classifiers"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , the most accurate classifiers typically have significantly high storage costs , or require complicated procedures that may be computationally expensive"], ["BODY", "we present a novel ( nonlinear ) classification approach using truncation of local tensor singular value decompositions ( tsvd ) that robustly offers accurate results , while maintaining manageable storage costs"], ["BODY", "our approach takes advantage of the optimality of the representation under the tensor algebra described to determine to which class an image belongs"], ["BODY", "we extend our approach to a method that can determine specific pairwise match scores , which could be useful in , for example , object recognition problems where pose/position are different"], ["CONCLUSION", "we demonstrate the promise of our new techniques on the mnist data set ."]], "topics": ["nonlinear system", "computer vision"]}
{"title": "a self-training method for semi-supervised gans", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "since the creation of generative adversarial networks ( gans ) , much work has been done to improve their training stability , their generated image quality , their range of application but nearly none of them explored their self-training potential"], ["INTRODUCTION", "self-training has been used before the advent of deep learning in order to allow training on limited labelled training data and has shown impressive results in semi-supervised learning"], ["BODY", "in this work , we combine these two ideas and make gans self-trainable for semi-supervised learning tasks by exploiting their infinite data generation potential"], ["BODY", "results show that using even the simplest form of self-training yields an improvement"], ["CONCLUSION", "we also show results for a more complex self-training scheme that performs at least as well as the basic self-training scheme but with significantly less data augmentation ."]], "topics": ["test set", "supervised learning"]}
{"title": "map estimation , linear programming and belief propagation with convex free energies", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "finding the most probable assignment ( map ) in a general graphical model is known to be np hard but good approximations have been attained with max-product belief propagation ( bp ) and its variants"], ["INTRODUCTION", "in particular , it is known that using bp on a single-cycle graph or tree reweighted bp on an arbitrary graph will give the map solution if the beliefs have no ties"], ["BODY", "in this paper we extend the setting under which bp can be used to provably extract the map"], ["BODY", "we define convex bp as bp algorithms based on a convex free energy approximation and show that this class includes ordinary bp with single-cycle , tree reweighted bp and many other bp variants"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show that when there are no ties , fixed-points of convex max-product bp will provably give the map solution"], ["CONCLUSION", "we also show that convex sum-product bp at sufficiently small temperatures can be used to solve linear programs that arise from relaxing the map problem"], ["CONCLUSION", "finally , we derive a novel condition that allows us to derive the map solution even if some of the convex bp beliefs have ties"], ["CONCLUSION", "in experiments , we show that our theorems allow us to find the map in many real-world instances of graphical models where exact inference using junction-tree is impossible ."]], "topics": ["graphical model", "approximation"]}
{"title": "computational investigation of low-discrepancy sequences in simulation algorithms for bayesian networks", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "monte carlo sampling has become a major vehicle for approximate inference in bayesian networks"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we investigate a family of related simulation approaches , known collectively as quasi-monte carlo methods based on deterministic low-discrepancy sequences"], ["BODY", "we first outline several theoretical aspects of deterministic low-discrepancy sequences , show three examples of such sequences , and then discuss practical issues related to applying them to belief updating in bayesian networks"], ["BODY", "we propose an algorithm for selecting direction numbers for sobol sequence"], ["CONCLUSION", "our experimental results show that low-discrepancy sequences ( especially sobol sequence ) significantly improve the performance of simulation algorithms in bayesian networks compared to monte carlo sampling ."]], "topics": ["sampling ( signal processing )", "simulation"]}
{"title": "computational ghost imaging using deep learning", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "computational ghost imaging ( cgi ) is a single-pixel imaging technique that exploits the correlation between known random patterns and the measured intensity of light transmitted ( or reflected ) by an object"], ["INTRODUCTION", "although cgi can obtain two- or three- dimensional images with a single or a few bucket detectors , the quality of the reconstructed images is reduced by noise due to the reconstruction of images from random patterns"], ["BODY", "in this study , we improve the quality of cgi images using deep learning"], ["BODY", "a deep neural network is used to automatically learn the features of noise-contaminated cgi images"], ["CONCLUSION", "after training , the network is able to predict low-noise images from new noise-contaminated cgi images ."]], "topics": ["pixel"]}
{"title": "good features to correlate for visual tracking", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "during the recent years , correlation filters have shown dominant and spectacular results for visual object tracking"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the types of the features that are employed in these family of trackers significantly affect the performance of visual tracking"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the ultimate goal is to utilize robust features invariant to any kind of appearance change of the object , while predicting the object location as properly as in the case of no appearance change"], ["INTRODUCTION", "as the deep learning based methods have emerged , the study of learning features for specific tasks has accelerated"], ["INTRODUCTION", "for instance , discriminative visual tracking methods based on deep architectures have been studied with promising performance"], ["INTRODUCTION", "nevertheless , correlation filter based ( cfb ) trackers confine themselves to use the pre-trained networks which are trained for object classification problem"], ["BODY", "to this end , in this manuscript the problem of learning deep fully convolutional features for the cfb visual tracking is formulated"], ["BODY", "in order to learn the proposed model , a novel and efficient backpropagation algorithm is presented based on the loss function of the network"], ["BODY", "the proposed learning framework enables the network model to be flexible for a custom design"], ["BODY", "moreover , it alleviates the dependency on the network trained for classification"], ["CONCLUSION", "extensive performance analysis shows the efficacy of the proposed custom design in the cfb tracking framework"], ["CONCLUSION", "by fine-tuning the convolutional parts of a state-of-the-art network and integrating this model to a cfb tracker , which is the top performing one of vot2016 , 18 % increase is achieved in terms of expected average overlap , and tracking failures are decreased by 25 % , while maintaining the superiority over the state-of-the-art methods in otb-2013 and otb-2015 tracking datasets ."]], "topics": ["loss function"]}
{"title": "the relative performance of ensemble methods with deep convolutional neural networks for image classification", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "artificial neural networks have been successfully applied to a variety of machine learning tasks , including image recognition , semantic segmentation , and machine translation"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , few studies fully investigated ensembles of artificial neural networks"], ["BODY", "in this work , we investigated multiple widely used ensemble methods , including unweighted averaging , majority voting , the bayes optimal classifier , and the ( discrete ) super learner , for image recognition tasks , with deep neural networks as candidate algorithms"], ["BODY", "we designed several experiments , with the candidate algorithms being the same network structure with different model checkpoints within a single training process , networks with same structure but trained multiple times stochastically , and networks with different structure"], ["BODY", "in addition , we further studied the over-confidence phenomenon of the neural networks , as well as its impact on the ensemble methods"], ["CONCLUSION", "across all of our experiments , the super learner achieved best performance among all the ensemble methods in this study ."]], "topics": ["neural networks", "machine translation"]}
{"title": "modelling constraint solver architecture design as a constraint problem", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "designing component-based constraint solvers is a complex problem"], ["INTRODUCTION", "some components are required , some are optional and there are interdependencies between the components"], ["INTRODUCTION", "because of this , previous approaches to solver design and modification have been ad-hoc and limited"], ["BODY", "we present a system that transforms a description of the components and the characteristics of the target constraint solver into a constraint problem"], ["BODY", "solving this problem yields the description of a valid solver"], ["CONCLUSION", "our approach represents a significant step towards the automated design and synthesis of constraint solvers that are specialised for individual constraint problem classes or instances ."]], "topics": ["mathematical optimization"]}
{"title": "learning with group invariant features : a kernel perspective", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we analyze in this paper a random feature map based on a theory of invariance i-theory introduced recently"], ["BODY", "more specifically , a group invariant signal signature is obtained through cumulative distributions of group transformed random projections"], ["BODY", "our analysis bridges invariant feature learning with kernel methods , as we show that this feature map defines an expected haar integration kernel that is invariant to the specified group action"], ["BODY", "we show how this non-linear random feature map approximates this group invariant kernel uniformly on a set of $ n $ points"], ["CONCLUSION", "moreover , we show that it defines a function space that is dense in the equivalent invariant reproducing kernel hilbert space"], ["CONCLUSION", "finally , we quantify error rates of the convergence of the empirical risk minimization , as well as the reduction in the sample complexity of a learning algorithm using such an invariant representation for signal classification , in a classical supervised learning setting ."]], "topics": ["kernel ( operating system )", "feature learning"]}
{"title": "influence of the event rate on discrimination abilities of bankruptcy prediction models", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in bankruptcy prediction , the proportion of events is very low , which is often oversampled to eliminate this bias"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we study the influence of the event rate on discrimination abilities of bankruptcy prediction models"], ["BODY", "first the statistical association and significance of public records and firmographics indicators with the bankruptcy were explored"], ["BODY", "then the event rate was oversampled from 0.12 % to 10 % , 20 % , 30 % , 40 % , and 50 % , respectively"], ["BODY", "seven models were developed , including logistic regression , decision tree , random forest , gradient boosting , support vector machine , bayesian network , and neural network"], ["BODY", "under different event rates , models were comprehensively evaluated and compared based on kolmogorov-smirnov statistic , accuracy , f1 score , type i error , type ii error , and roc curve on the hold-out dataset with their best probability cut-offs"], ["CONCLUSION", "results show that bayesian network is the most insensitive to the event rate , while support vector machine is the most sensitive ."]], "topics": ["support vector machine", "bayesian network"]}
{"title": "a deep compositional framework for human-like language acquisition in virtual environment", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we tackle a task where an agent learns to navigate in a 2d maze-like environment called xworld"], ["BODY", "in each session , the agent perceives a sequence of raw-pixel frames , a natural language command issued by a teacher , and a set of rewards"], ["BODY", "the agent learns the teacher 's language from scratch in a grounded and compositional manner , such that after training it is able to correctly execute zero-shot commands : 1 ) the combination of words in the command never appeared before , and/or 2 ) the command contains new object concepts that are learned from another task but never learned from navigation"], ["BODY", "our deep framework for the agent is trained end to end : it learns simultaneously the visual representations of the environment , the syntax and semantics of the language , and the action module that outputs actions"], ["BODY", "the zero-shot learning capability of our framework results from its compositionality and modularity with parameter tying"], ["CONCLUSION", "we visualize the intermediate outputs of the framework , demonstrating that the agent truly understands how to solve the problem"], ["CONCLUSION", "we believe that our results provide some preliminary insights on how to train an agent with similar abilities in a 3d environment ."]], "topics": ["natural language", "pixel"]}
{"title": "parsing with typed feature structures", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in this paper we provide for parsing with respect to grammars expressed in a general tfs-based formalism , a restriction of ale"], ["BODY", "our motivation being the design of an abstract ( wam-like ) machine for the formalism , we consider parsing as a computational process and use it as an operational semantics to guide the design of the control structures for the abstract machine"], ["BODY", "we emphasize the notion of abstract typed feature structures ( afss ) that encode the essential information of tfss and define unification over afss rather than over tfss"], ["BODY", "we then introduce an explicit construct of multi-rooted feature structures ( mrss ) that naturally extend tfss and use them to represent phrasal signs as well as grammar rules"], ["BODY", "we also employ abstractions of mrss and give the mathematical foundations needed for manipulating them"], ["CONCLUSION", "we then present a simple bottom-up chart parser as a model for computation : grammars written in the tfs-based formalism are executed by the parser"], ["CONCLUSION", "finally , we show that the parser is correct ."]], "topics": ["parsing", "computation"]}
{"title": "long-term temporal convolutions for action recognition", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "typical human actions last several seconds and exhibit characteristic spatio-temporal structure"], ["INTRODUCTION", "recent methods attempt to capture this structure and learn action representations with convolutional neural networks"], ["INTRODUCTION", "such representations , however , are typically learned at the level of a few video frames failing to model actions at their full temporal extent"], ["BODY", "in this work we learn video representations using neural networks with long-term temporal convolutions ( ltc )"], ["BODY", "we demonstrate that ltc-cnn models with increased temporal extents improve the accuracy of action recognition"], ["BODY", "we also study the impact of different low-level representations , such as raw values of video pixels and optical flow vector fields and demonstrate the importance of high-quality optical flow estimation for learning accurate action models"], ["CONCLUSION", "we report state-of-the-art results on two challenging benchmarks for human action recognition ucf101 ( 92.7 % ) and hmdb51 ( 67.2 % ) ."]], "topics": ["high- and low-level", "convolution"]}
{"title": "semi-supervised learning with the deep rendering mixture model", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "semi-supervised learning algorithms reduce the high cost of acquiring labeled training data by using both labeled and unlabeled data during learning"], ["INTRODUCTION", "deep convolutional networks ( dcns ) have achieved great success in supervised tasks and as such have been widely employed in the semi-supervised learning"], ["BODY", "in this paper we leverage the recently developed deep rendering mixture model ( drmm ) , a probabilistic generative model that models latent nuisance variation , and whose inference algorithm yields dcns"], ["BODY", "we develop an em algorithm for the drmm to learn from both labeled and unlabeled data"], ["BODY", "guided by the theory of the drmm , we introduce a novel non-negativity constraint and a variational inference term"], ["CONCLUSION", "we report state-of-the-art performance on mnist and svhn and competitive results on cifar10"], ["CONCLUSION", "we also probe deeper into how a drmm trained in a semi-supervised setting represents latent nuisance variation using synthetically rendered images"], ["CONCLUSION", "taken together , our work provides a unified framework for supervised , unsupervised , and semi-supervised learning ."]], "topics": ["generative model", "test set"]}
{"title": "localizing by describing : attribute-guided attention localization for fine-grained recognition", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "a key challenge in fine-grained recognition is how to find and represent discriminative local regions"], ["INTRODUCTION", "recent attention models are capable of learning discriminative region localizers only from category labels with reinforcement learning"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , not utilizing any explicit part information , they are not able to accurately find multiple distinctive regions"], ["BODY", "in this work , we introduce an attribute-guided attention localization scheme where the local region localizers are learned under the guidance of part attribute descriptions"], ["BODY", "by designing a novel reward strategy , we are able to learn to locate regions that are spatially and semantically distinctive with reinforcement learning algorithm"], ["BODY", "the attribute labeling requirement of the scheme is more amenable than the accurate part location annotation required by traditional part-based fine-grained recognition methods"], ["CONCLUSION", "experimental results on the cub-200-2011 dataset demonstrate the superiority of the proposed scheme on both fine-grained recognition and attribute recognition ."]], "topics": ["reinforcement learning"]}
{"title": "learning hidden markov models with geometrical constraints", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "hidden markov models ( hmms ) and partially observable markov decision processes ( pomdps ) form a useful tool for modeling dynamical systems"], ["INTRODUCTION", "they are particularly useful for representing environments such as road networks and office buildings , which are typical for robot navigation and planning"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the work presented here is concerned with acquiring such models"], ["BODY", "we demonstrate how domain-specific information and constraints can be incorporated into the statistical estimation process , greatly improving the learned models in terms of the model quality , the number of iterations required for convergence and robustness to reduction in the amount of available data"], ["BODY", "we present new initialization heuristics which can be used even when the data suffers from cumulative rotational error , new update rules for the model parameters , as an instance of generalized em , and a strategy for enforcing complete geometrical consistency in the model"], ["CONCLUSION", "experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach for both simulated and real robot data , in traditionally hard-to-learn environments ."]], "topics": ["simulation", "iteration"]}
{"title": "multi-q pattern classification of polarization curves", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "several experimental measurements are expressed in the form of one-dimensional profiles , for which there is a scarcity of methodologies able to classify the pertinence of a given result to a specific group"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the polarization curves that evaluate the corrosion kinetics of electrodes in corrosive media are an application where the behavior is chiefly analyzed from profiles"], ["INTRODUCTION", "polarization curves are indeed a classic method to determine the global kinetics of metallic electrodes , but the strong nonlinearity from different metals and alloys can overlap and the discrimination becomes a challenging problem"], ["INTRODUCTION", "moreover , even finding a typical curve from replicated tests requires subjective judgement"], ["BODY", "in this paper we used the so-called multi-q approach based on the tsallis statistics in a classification engine to separate multiple polarization curve profiles of two stainless steels"], ["BODY", "we collected 48 experimental polarization curves in aqueous chloride medium of two stainless steel types , with different resistance against localized corrosion"], ["BODY", "multi-q pattern analysis was then carried out on a wide potential range , from cathodic up to anodic regions"], ["CONCLUSION", "an excellent classification rate was obtained , at a success rate of 90 % , 80 % , and 83 % for low ( cathodic ) , high ( anodic ) , and both potential ranges , respectively , using only 2 % of the original profile data"], ["CONCLUSION", "these results show the potential of the proposed approach towards efficient , robust , systematic and automatic classification of highly non-linear profile curves ."]], "topics": ["nonlinear system", "relevance"]}
{"title": "unsupervised feature learning based on deep models for environmental audio tagging", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "environmental audio tagging aims to predict only the presence or absence of certain acoustic events in the interested acoustic scene"], ["BODY", "in this paper we make contributions to audio tagging in two parts , respectively , acoustic modeling and feature learning"], ["BODY", "we propose to use a shrinking deep neural network ( dnn ) framework incorporating unsupervised feature learning to handle the multi-label classification task"], ["BODY", "for the acoustic modeling , a large set of contextual frames of the chunk are fed into the dnn to perform a multi-label classification for the expected tags , considering that only chunk ( or utterance ) level rather than frame-level labels are available"], ["BODY", "dropout and background noise aware training are also adopted to improve the generalization capability of the dnns"], ["BODY", "for the unsupervised feature learning , we propose to use a symmetric or asymmetric deep de-noising auto-encoder ( sdae or adae ) to generate new data-driven features from the mel-filter banks ( mfbs ) features"], ["BODY", "the new features , which are smoothed against background noise and more compact with contextual information , can further improve the performance of the dnn baseline"], ["CONCLUSION", "compared with the standard gaussian mixture model ( gmm ) baseline of the dcase 2016 audio tagging challenge , our proposed method obtains a significant equal error rate ( eer ) reduction from 0.21 to 0.13 on the development set"], ["CONCLUSION", "the proposed adae system can get a relative 6.7 % eer reduction compared with the strong dnn baseline on the development set"], ["CONCLUSION", "finally , the results also show that our approach obtains the state-of-the-art performance with 0.15 eer on the evaluation set of the dcase 2016 audio tagging task while eer of the first prize of this challenge is 0.17 ."]], "topics": ["baseline ( configuration management )", "feature learning"]}

{"title": "novel exploration techniques ( nets ) for malaria policy interventions", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the task of decision-making under uncertainty is daunting , especially for problems which have significant complexity"], ["INTRODUCTION", "healthcare policy makers across the globe are facing problems under challenging constraints , with limited tools to help them make data driven decisions"], ["BODY", "in this work we frame the process of finding an optimal malaria policy as a stochastic multi-armed bandit problem , and implement three agent based strategies to explore the policy space"], ["BODY", "we apply a gaussian process regression to the findings of each agent , both for comparison and to account for stochastic results from simulating the spread of malaria in a fixed population"], ["BODY", "the generated policy spaces are compared with published results to give a direct reference with human expert decisions for the same simulated population"], ["CONCLUSION", "our novel approach provides a powerful resource for policy makers , and a platform which can be readily extended to capture future more nuanced policy spaces ."]], "topics": ["simulation"]}
{"title": "signed laplacian for spectral clustering revisited", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "classical spectral clustering is based on a spectral decomposition of a graph laplacian , obtained from a graph adjacency matrix representing positive graph edge weights describing similarities of graph vertices"], ["BODY", "in signed graphs , the graph edge weights can be negative to describe disparities of graph vertices , for example , negative correlations in the data"], ["BODY", "negative weights lead to possible negative spectrum of the standard graph laplacian , which is cured by defining a signed laplacian"], ["CONCLUSION", "we revisit comparing the standard and signed laplacians and argue that the former is more natural than the latter , also showing that the negative spectrum is actually beneficial , for spectral clustering of signed graphs ."]], "topics": ["cluster analysis"]}
{"title": "improving visually grounded sentence representations with self-attention", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "sentence representation models trained only on language could potentially suffer from the grounding problem"], ["INTRODUCTION", "recent work has shown promising results in improving the qualities of sentence representations by jointly training them with associated image features"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , the grounding capability is limited due to distant connection between input sentences and image features by the design of the architecture"], ["BODY", "in order to further close the gap , we propose applying self-attention mechanism to the sentence encoder to deepen the grounding effect"], ["BODY", "our results on transfer tasks show that self-attentive encoders are better for visual grounding , as they exploit specific words with strong visual associations ."]], "topics": ["encoder"]}
{"title": "budget online multiple kernel learning", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "online learning with multiple kernels has gained increasing interests in recent years and found many applications"], ["INTRODUCTION", "for classification tasks , online multiple kernel classification ( omkc ) , which learns a kernel based classifier by seeking the optimal linear combination of a pool of single kernel classifiers in an online fashion , achieves superior accuracy and enjoys great flexibility compared with traditional single-kernel classifiers"], ["INTRODUCTION", "despite being studied extensively , existing omkc algorithms suffer from high computational cost due to their unbounded numbers of support vectors"], ["BODY", "to overcome this drawback , we present a novel framework of budget online multiple kernel learning ( bomkl ) and propose a new sparse passive aggressive learning to perform effective budget online learning"], ["BODY", "specifically , we adopt a simple yet effective bernoulli sampling to decide if an incoming instance should be added to the current set of support vectors"], ["BODY", "by limiting the number of support vectors , our method can significantly accelerate omkc while maintaining satisfactory accuracy that is comparable to that of the existing omkc algorithms"], ["CONCLUSION", "we theoretically prove that our new method achieves an optimal regret bound in expectation , and empirically found that the proposed algorithm outperforms various omkc algorithms and can easily scale up to large-scale datasets ."]], "topics": ["kernel ( operating system )", "sampling ( signal processing )"]}
{"title": "a multi-feature tracking algorithm enabling adaptation to context variations", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose in this paper a tracking algorithm which is able to adapt itself to different scene contexts"], ["BODY", "a feature pool is used to compute the matching score between two detected objects"], ["BODY", "this feature pool includes 2d , 3d displacement distances , 2d sizes , color histogram , histogram of oriented gradient ( hog ) , color covariance and dominant color"], ["BODY", "an offline learning process is proposed to search for useful features and to estimate their weights for each context"], ["BODY", "in the online tracking process , a temporal window is defined to establish the links between the detected objects"], ["BODY", "this enables to find the object trajectories even if the objects are misdetected in some frames"], ["BODY", "a trajectory filter is proposed to remove noisy trajectories"], ["BODY", "experimentation on different contexts is shown"], ["CONCLUSION", "the proposed tracker has been tested in videos belonging to three public datasets and to the caretaker european project"], ["CONCLUSION", "the experimental results prove the effect of the proposed feature weight learning , and the robustness of the proposed tracker compared to some methods in the state of the art"], ["CONCLUSION", "the contributions of our approach over the state of the art trackers are : ( i ) a robust tracking algorithm based on a feature pool , ( ii ) a supervised learning scheme to learn feature weights for each context , ( iii ) a new method to quantify the reliability of hog descriptor , ( iv ) a combination of color covariance and dominant color features with spatial pyramid distance to manage the case of object occlusion ."]], "topics": ["supervised learning"]}
{"title": "deeply coupled auto-encoder networks for cross-view classification", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the comparison of heterogeneous samples extensively exists in many applications , especially in the task of image classification"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we propose a simple but effective coupled neural network , called deeply coupled autoencoder networks ( dcan ) , which seeks to build two deep neural networks , coupled with each other in every corresponding layers"], ["BODY", "in dcan , each deep structure is developed via stacking multiple discriminative coupled auto-encoders , a denoising auto-encoder trained with maximum margin criterion consisting of intra-class compactness and inter-class penalty"], ["BODY", "this single layer component makes our model simultaneously preserve the local consistency and enhance its discriminative capability"], ["BODY", "with increasing number of layers , the coupled networks can gradually narrow the gap between the two views"], ["CONCLUSION", "extensive experiments on cross-view image classification tasks demonstrate the superiority of our method over state-of-the-art methods ."]], "topics": ["noise reduction", "computer vision"]}
{"title": "automatic face reenactment", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose an image-based , facial reenactment system that replaces the face of an actor in an existing target video with the face of a user from a source video , while preserving the original target performance"], ["BODY", "our system is fully automatic and does not require a database of source expressions"], ["BODY", "instead , it is able to produce convincing reenactment results from a short source video captured with an off-the-shelf camera , such as a webcam , where the user performs arbitrary facial gestures"], ["BODY", "our reenactment pipeline is conceived as part image retrieval and part face transfer : the image retrieval is based on temporal clustering of target frames and a novel image matching metric that combines appearance and motion to select candidate frames from the source video , while the face transfer uses a 2d warping strategy that preserves the user 's identity"], ["BODY", "our system excels in simplicity as it does not rely on a 3d face model , it is robust under head motion and does not require the source and target performance to be similar"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show convincing reenactment results for videos that we recorded ourselves and for low-quality footage taken from the internet ."]], "topics": ["cluster analysis", "database"]}
{"title": "dual attention matching network for context-aware feature sequence based person re-identification", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "typical person re-identification ( reid ) methods usually describe each pedestrian with a single feature vector and match them in a task-specific metric space"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , the methods based on a single feature vector are not sufficient enough to overcome visual ambiguity , which frequently occurs in real scenario"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we propose a novel end-to-end trainable framework , called dual attention matching network ( duatm ) , to learn context-aware feature sequences and perform attentive sequence comparison simultaneously"], ["BODY", "the core component of our duatm framework is a dual attention mechanism , in which both intra-sequence and inter-sequence attention strategies are used for feature refinement and feature-pair alignment , respectively"], ["BODY", "thus , detailed visual cues contained in the intermediate feature sequences can be automatically exploited and properly compared"], ["BODY", "we train the proposed duatm network as a siamese network via a triplet loss assisted with a de-correlation loss and a cross-entropy loss"], ["CONCLUSION", "we conduct extensive experiments on both image and video based reid benchmark datasets"], ["CONCLUSION", "experimental results demonstrate the significant advantages of our approach compared to the state-of-the-art methods ."]], "topics": ["feature vector"]}
{"title": "hyperspectral image classification and clutter detection via multiple structural embeddings and dimension reductions", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we present a new and effective approach for hyperspectral image ( hsi ) classification and clutter detection , overcoming a few long-standing challenges presented by hsi data characteristics"], ["BODY", "residing in a high-dimensional spectral attribute space , hsi data samples are known to be strongly correlated in their spectral signatures , exhibit nonlinear structure due to several physical laws , and contain uncertainty and noise from multiple sources"], ["BODY", "in the presented approach , we generate an adaptive , structurally enriched representation environment , and employ the locally linear embedding ( lle ) in it"], ["BODY", "there are two structure layers external to lle"], ["BODY", "one is feature space embedding : the hsi data attributes are embedded into a discriminatory feature space where spatio-spectral coherence and distinctive structures are distilled and exploited to mitigate various difficulties encountered in the native hyperspectral attribute space"], ["BODY", "the other structure layer encloses the ranges of algorithmic parameters for lle and feature embedding , and supports a multiplexing and integrating scheme for contending with multi-source uncertainty"], ["CONCLUSION", "experiments on two commonly used hsi datasets with a small number of learning samples have rendered remarkably high-accuracy classification results , as well as distinctive maps of detected clutter regions ."]], "topics": ["feature vector", "nonlinear system"]}
{"title": "hierarchical cross network for person re-identification", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "person re-identification ( person re-id ) aims at matching target person ( s ) grabbed from different and non-overlapping camera views"], ["INTRODUCTION", "it plays an important role for public safety and has application in various tasks such as , human retrieval , human tracking , and activity analysis"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we propose a new network architecture called hierarchical cross network ( hcn ) to perform person re-id"], ["BODY", "in addition to the backbone model of a conventional cnn , hcn is equipped with two additional maps called hierarchical cross feature maps"], ["BODY", "the maps of an hcn are formed by merging layers with different resolutions and semantic levels"], ["BODY", "with the hierarchical cross feature maps , an hcn can effectively uncover additional semantic features which could not be discovered by a conventional cnn"], ["BODY", "although the proposed hcn can discover features with higher semantics , its representation power is still limited"], ["BODY", "to derive more general representations , we augment the data during the training process by combining multiple datasets"], ["CONCLUSION", "experiment results show that the proposed method outperformed several state-of-the-art methods ."]], "topics": ["map"]}
