["INTRODUCTION", "artificial neural network are a widely used class of algorithms for non-parametric system identification , among them , the nonlinear auto regressive exogeneous input network ( narx ) model is very popular , but it also necessitates some in depth knowledge regarding the system being modeled"], ["INTRODUCTION", "there have been many approaches proposed to circumvent this and yet still retain the advantageous characteristics"], ["BODY", "in this paper we carry out an extensive study of one such newly proposed approach using a modified narx model with a two tiered , externally driven recurrent neural network architecture"], ["BODY", "this is coupled with an outer optimization routine for evolving the order of the system"], ["BODY", "this generic architecture is comprehensively explored to ascertain its usability and critically asses its potential"], ["BODY", "different instantiations of this architecture , based on nature inspired computational techniques ( artificial bee colony , artificial immune system and particle swarm optimization ) are evaluated and critically compared in this paper"], ["BODY", "simulations have been carried out for identifying the longitudinally uncoupled dynamics"], ["CONCLUSION", "results of identification indicate a quite close correlation between the actual and the predicted response of the helicopter for all the models ."]], "topics": ["recurrent neural network", "nonlinear system"]}
{"title": "neural system identification for large populations separating `` what '' and `` where ''", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "neuroscientists classify neurons into different types that perform similar computations at different locations in the visual field"], ["INTRODUCTION", "traditional methods for neural system identification do not capitalize on this separation of 'what ' and 'where '"], ["INTRODUCTION", "learning deep convolutional feature spaces that are shared among many neurons provides an exciting path forward , but the architectural design needs to account for data limitations : while new experimental techniques enable recordings from thousands of neurons , experimental time is limited so that one can sample only a small fraction of each neuron 's response space"], ["BODY", "here , we show that a major bottleneck for fitting convolutional neural networks ( cnns ) to neural data is the estimation of the individual receptive field locations , a problem that has been scratched only at the surface thus far"], ["BODY", "we propose a cnn architecture with a sparse readout layer factorizing the spatial ( where ) and feature ( what ) dimensions"], ["BODY", "our network scales well to thousands of neurons and short recordings and can be trained end-to-end"], ["BODY", "we evaluate this architecture on ground-truth data to explore the challenges and limitations of cnn-based system identification"], ["CONCLUSION", "moreover , we show that our network model outperforms current state-of-the art system identification models of mouse primary visual cortex ."]], "topics": ["sparse matrix", "end-to-end principle"]}
{"title": "revisiting the vector space model : sparse weighted nearest-neighbor method for extreme multi-label classification", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "machine learning has played an important role in information retrieval ( ir ) in recent times"], ["INTRODUCTION", "in search engines , for example , query keywords are accepted and documents are returned in order of relevance to the given query ; this can be cast as a multi-label ranking problem in machine learning"], ["INTRODUCTION", "generally , the number of candidate documents is extremely large ( from several thousand to several million ) ; thus , the classifier must handle many labels"], ["INTRODUCTION", "this problem is referred to as extreme multi-label classification ( xmlc )"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we propose a novel approach to xmlc termed the sparse weighted nearest-neighbor method"], ["BODY", "this technique can be derived as a fast implementation of state-of-the-art ( sota ) one-versus-rest linear classifiers for very sparse datasets"], ["CONCLUSION", "in addition , we show that the classifier can be written as a sparse generalization of a representer theorem with a linear kernel"], ["CONCLUSION", "furthermore , our method can be viewed as the vector space model used in ir"], ["CONCLUSION", "finally , we show that the sparse weighted nearest-neighbor method can process data points in real time on xmlc datasets with equivalent performance to sota models , with a single thread and smaller storage footprint"], ["CONCLUSION", "in particular , our method exhibits superior performance to the sota models on a dataset with 3 million labels ."]], "topics": ["statistical classification", "sparse matrix"]}
{"title": "vocabulary selection strategies for neural machine translation", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "classical translation models constrain the space of possible outputs by selecting a subset of translation rules based on the input sentence"], ["INTRODUCTION", "recent work on improving the efficiency of neural translation models adopted a similar strategy by restricting the output vocabulary to a subset of likely candidates given the source"], ["BODY", "in this paper we experiment with context and embedding-based selection methods and extend previous work by examining speed and accuracy trade-offs in more detail"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show that decoding time on cpus can be reduced by up to 90 % and training time by 25 % on the wmt15 english-german and wmt16 english-romanian tasks at the same or only negligible change in accuracy"], ["CONCLUSION", "this brings the time to decode with a state of the art neural translation system to just over 140 msec per sentence on a single cpu core for english-german ."]], "topics": ["machine translation"]}
{"title": "deeppermnet : visual permutation learning", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we present a principled approach to uncover the structure of visual data by solving a novel deep learning task coined visual permutation learning"], ["BODY", "the goal of this task is to find the permutation that recovers the structure of data from shuffled versions of it"], ["BODY", "in the case of natural images , this task boils down to recovering the original image from patches shuffled by an unknown permutation matrix"], ["BODY", "unfortunately , permutation matrices are discrete , thereby posing difficulties for gradient-based methods"], ["BODY", "to this end , we resort to a continuous approximation of these matrices using doubly-stochastic matrices which we generate from standard cnn predictions using sinkhorn iterations"], ["BODY", "unrolling these iterations in a sinkhorn network layer , we propose deeppermnet , an end-to-end cnn model for this task"], ["BODY", "the utility of deeppermnet is demonstrated on two challenging computer vision problems , namely , ( i ) relative attributes learning and ( ii ) self-supervised representation learning"], ["CONCLUSION", "our results show state-of-the-art performance on the public figures and osr benchmarks for ( i ) and on the classification and segmentation tasks on the pascal voc dataset for ( ii ) ."]], "topics": ["feature learning", "computer vision"]}
{"title": "learning to search with mctsnets", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "planning problems are among the most important and well-studied problems in artificial intelligence"], ["INTRODUCTION", "they are most typically solved by tree search algorithms that simulate ahead into the future , evaluate future states , and back-up those evaluations to the root of a search tree"], ["INTRODUCTION", "among these algorithms , monte-carlo tree search ( mcts ) is one of the most general , powerful and widely used"], ["INTRODUCTION", "a typical implementation of mcts uses cleverly designed rules , optimized to the particular characteristics of the domain"], ["INTRODUCTION", "these rules control where the simulation traverses , what to evaluate in the states that are reached , and how to back-up those evaluations"], ["BODY", "in this paper we instead learn where , what and how to search"], ["BODY", "our architecture , which we call an mctsnet , incorporates simulation-based search inside a neural network , by expanding , evaluating and backing-up a vector embedding"], ["BODY", "the parameters of the network are trained end-to-end using gradient-based optimisation"], ["CONCLUSION", "when applied to small searches in the well known planning problem sokoban , the learned search algorithm significantly outperformed mcts baselines ."]], "topics": ["mathematical optimization", "simulation"]}
{"title": "birdnest : bayesian inference for ratings-fraud detection", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "review fraud is a pervasive problem in online commerce , in which fraudulent sellers write or purchase fake reviews to manipulate perception of their products and services"], ["INTRODUCTION", "fake reviews are often detected based on several signs , including 1 ) they occur in short bursts of time ; 2 ) fraudulent user accounts have skewed rating distributions"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , these may both be true in any given dataset"], ["BODY", "hence , in this paper , we propose an approach for detecting fraudulent reviews which combines these 2 approaches in a principled manner , allowing successful detection even when one of these signs is not present"], ["BODY", "to combine these 2 approaches , we formulate our bayesian inference for rating data ( bird ) model , a flexible bayesian model of user rating behavior"], ["BODY", "based on our model we formulate a likelihood-based suspiciousness metric , normalized expected surprise total ( nest )"], ["BODY", "we propose a linear-time algorithm for performing bayesian inference using our model and computing the metric"], ["CONCLUSION", "experiments on real data show that birdnest successfully spots review fraud in large , real-world graphs : the 50 most suspicious users of the flipkart platform flagged by our algorithm were investigated and all identified as fraudulent by domain experts at flipkart ."]], "topics": ["time complexity", "bayesian network"]}
{"title": "a learning approach to shallow parsing", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "a snow based learning approach to shallow parsing tasks is presented and studied experimentally"], ["BODY", "the approach learns to identify syntactic patterns by combining simple predictors to produce a coherent inference"], ["BODY", "two instantiations of this approach are studied and experimental results for noun-phrases ( np ) and subject-verb ( sv ) phrases that compare favorably with the best published results are presented"], ["CONCLUSION", "in doing that , we compare two ways of modeling the problem of learning to recognize patterns and suggest that shallow parsing patterns are better learned using open/close predictors than using inside/outside predictors ."]], "topics": ["parsing"]}
{"title": "proximal methods for hierarchical sparse coding", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "sparse coding consists in representing signals as sparse linear combinations of atoms selected from a dictionary"], ["BODY", "we consider an extension of this framework where the atoms are further assumed to be embedded in a tree"], ["BODY", "this is achieved using a recently introduced tree-structured sparse regularization norm , which has proven useful in several applications"], ["BODY", "this norm leads to regularized problems that are difficult to optimize , and we propose in this paper efficient algorithms for solving them"], ["CONCLUSION", "more precisely , we show that the proximal operator associated with this norm is computable exactly via a dual approach that can be viewed as the composition of elementary proximal operators"], ["CONCLUSION", "our procedure has a complexity linear , or close to linear , in the number of atoms , and allows the use of accelerated gradient techniques to solve the tree-structured sparse approximation problem at the same computational cost as traditional ones using the l1-norm"], ["CONCLUSION", "our method is efficient and scales gracefully to millions of variables , which we illustrate in two types of applications : first , we consider fixed hierarchical dictionaries of wavelets to denoise natural images"], ["CONCLUSION", "then , we apply our optimization tools in the context of dictionary learning , where learned dictionary elements naturally organize in a prespecified arborescent structure , leading to a better performance in reconstruction of natural image patches"], ["CONCLUSION", "when applied to text documents , our method learns hierarchies of topics , thus providing a competitive alternative to probabilistic topic models ."]], "topics": ["noise reduction", "matrix regularization"]}
{"title": "switching convolutional neural network for crowd counting", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose a novel crowd counting model that maps a given crowd scene to its density"], ["BODY", "crowd analysis is compounded by myriad of factors like inter-occlusion between people due to extreme crowding , high similarity of appearance between people and background elements , and large variability of camera view-points"], ["BODY", "current state-of-the art approaches tackle these factors by using multi-scale cnn architectures , recurrent networks and late fusion of features from multi-column cnn with different receptive fields"], ["BODY", "we propose switching convolutional neural network that leverages variation of crowd density within an image to improve the accuracy and localization of the predicted crowd count"], ["BODY", "patches from a grid within a crowd scene are relayed to independent cnn regressors based on crowd count prediction quality of the cnn established during training"], ["BODY", "the independent cnn regressors are designed to have different receptive fields and a switch classifier is trained to relay the crowd scene patch to the best cnn regressor"], ["CONCLUSION", "we perform extensive experiments on all major crowd counting datasets and evidence better performance compared to current state-of-the-art methods"], ["CONCLUSION", "we provide interpretable representations of the multichotomy of space of crowd scene patches inferred from the switch"], ["CONCLUSION", "it is observed that the switch relays an image patch to a particular cnn column based on density of crowd ."]], "topics": ["map"]}
{"title": "deepcorrect : correcting dnn models against image distortions", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in recent years , the widespread use of deep neural networks ( dnns ) has facilitated great improvements in performance for computer vision tasks like image classification and object recognition"], ["INTRODUCTION", "in most realistic computer vision applications , an input image undergoes some form of image distortion such as blur and additive noise during image acquisition or transmission"], ["INTRODUCTION", "deep networks trained on pristine images perform poorly when tested on such distortions"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we evaluate the effect of image distortions like gaussian blur and additive noise on the activations of pre-trained convolutional filters"], ["BODY", "we propose a metric to identify the most noise susceptible convolutional filters and rank them in order of the highest gain in classification accuracy upon correction"], ["BODY", "in our proposed approach called deepcorrect , we apply small stacks of convolutional layers with residual connections , at the output of these ranked filters and train them to correct the worst distortion affected filter activations , whilst leaving the rest of the pre-trained filter outputs in the network unchanged"], ["CONCLUSION", "performance results show that applying deepcorrect models for common vision tasks like image classification ( cifar-100 , imagenet ) , object recognition ( caltech-101 , caltech-256 ) and scene classification ( sun-397 ) , significantly improves the robustness of dnns against distorted images and outperforms the alternative approach of network fine-tuning ."]], "topics": ["computer vision"]}
{"title": "bit-planes : dense subpixel alignment of binary descriptors", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "binary descriptors have been instrumental in the recent evolution of computationally efficient sparse image alignment algorithms"], ["INTRODUCTION", "increasingly , however , the vision community is interested in dense image alignment methods , which are more suitable for estimating correspondences from high frame rate cameras as they do not rely on exhaustive search"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , classic dense alignment approaches are sensitive to illumination change"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we propose an easy to implement and low complexity dense binary descriptor , which we refer to as bit-planes , that can be seamlessly integrated within a multi-channel lucas & kanade framework"], ["BODY", "this novel approach combines the robustness of binary descriptors with the speed and accuracy of dense alignment methods"], ["CONCLUSION", "the approach is demonstrated on a template tracking problem achieving state-of-the-art robustness and faster than real-time performance on consumer laptops ( 400+ fps on a single core intel i7 ) and hand-held mobile devices ( 100+ fps on an ipad air 2 ) ."]], "topics": ["computational complexity theory", "sparse matrix"]}
{"title": "jointdnn : an efficient training and inference engine for intelligent mobile cloud computing services", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "deep neural networks are among the most influential architectures of deep learning algorithms , being deployed in many mobile intelligent applications"], ["INTRODUCTION", "end-side services , such as intelligent personal assistants ( ipas ) , autonomous cars , and smart home services often employ either simple local models or complex remote models on the cloud"], ["INTRODUCTION", "mobile-only and cloud-only computations are currently the status quo approaches"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we propose an efficient , adaptive , and practical engine , jointdnn , for collaborative computation between a mobile device and cloud for dnns in both inference and training phase"], ["BODY", "jointdnn not only provides an energy and performance efficient method of querying dnns for the mobile side , but also benefits the cloud server by reducing the amount of its workload and communications compared to the cloud-only approach"], ["BODY", "given the dnn architecture , we investigate the efficiency of processing some layers on the mobile device and some layers on the cloud server"], ["BODY", "we provide optimization formulations at layer granularity for forward and backward propagation in dnns , which can adapt to mobile battery limitations and cloud server load constraints and quality of service"], ["CONCLUSION", "jointdnn achieves up to 18x and 32x reductions on the latency and mobile energy consumption of querying dnns , respectively ."]], "topics": ["computation", "autonomous car"]}
{"title": "weighted contrastive divergence", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "learning algorithms for energy based boltzmann architectures that rely on gradient descent are in general computationally prohibitive , typically due to the exponential number of terms involved in computing the partition function"], ["INTRODUCTION", "in this way one has to resort to approximation schemes for the evaluation of the gradient"], ["INTRODUCTION", "this is the case of restricted boltzmann machines ( rbm ) and its learning algorithm contrastive divergence ( cd )"], ["INTRODUCTION", "it is well-known that cd has a number of shortcomings , and its approximation to the gradient has several drawbacks"], ["INTRODUCTION", "overcoming these defects has been the basis of much research and new algorithms have been devised , such as persistent cd"], ["BODY", "in this manuscript we propose a new algorithm that we call weighted cd ( wcd ) , built from small modifications of the negative phase in standard cd"], ["CONCLUSION", "however small these modifications may be , experimental work reported in this paper suggest that wcd provides a significant improvement over standard cd and persistent cd at a small additional computational cost ."]], "topics": ["time complexity", "gradient descent"]}
{"title": "a tool set for the quick and efficient exploration of large document collections", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we are presenting a set of multilingual text analysis tools that can help analysts in any field to explore large document collections quickly in order to determine whether the documents contain information of interest , and to find the relevant text passages"], ["BODY", "the automatic tool , which currently exists as a fully functional prototype , is expected to be particularly useful when users repeatedly have to sieve through large collections of documents such as those downloaded automatically from the internet"], ["BODY", "the proposed system takes a whole document collection as input"], ["BODY", "it first carries out some automatic analysis tasks ( named entity recognition , geo-coding , clustering , term extraction ) , annotates the texts with the generated meta-information and stores the meta-information in a database"], ["BODY", "the system then generates a zoomable and hyperlinked geographic map enhanced with information on entities and terms found"], ["CONCLUSION", "when the system is used on a regular basis , it builds up a historical database that contains information on which names have been mentioned together with which other names or places , and users can query this database to retrieve information extracted in the past ."]], "topics": ["entity"]}
{"title": "mscm-life : multi-scale cross modal linear feature for horizon detection in maritime images", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "this paper proposes a new method for horizon detection called the multi-scale cross modal linear feature"], ["BODY", "this method integrates three different concepts related to the presence of horizon in maritime images to increase the accuracy of horizon detection"], ["BODY", "specifically it uses the persistence of horizon in multi-scale median filtering , and its detection as a linear feature commonly detected by two different methods , namely the hough transform of edgemap and the intensity gradient"], ["CONCLUSION", "we demonstrate the performance of the method over 13 videos comprising of more than 3000 frames and show that the proposed method detects horizon with small error in most of the cases , outperforming three state-of-the-art methods ."]], "topics": ["gradient"]}
{"title": "understanding ( dis ) similarity measures", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "intuitively , the concept of similarity is the notion to measure an inexact matching between two entities of the same reference set"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the notions of similarity and its close relative dissimilarity are widely used in many fields of artificial intelligence"], ["INTRODUCTION", "yet they have many different and often partial definitions or properties , usually restricted to one field of application and thus incompatible with other uses"], ["BODY", "this paper contributes to the design and understanding of similarity and dissimilarity measures for artificial intelligence"], ["BODY", "a formal dual definition for each concept is proposed , joined with a set of fundamental properties"], ["CONCLUSION", "the behavior of the properties under several transformations is studied and revealed as an important matter to bear in mind"], ["CONCLUSION", "we also develop several practical examples that work out the proposed approach ."]], "topics": ["entity", "artificial intelligence"]}
{"title": "a variational approximation for bayesian networks with discrete and continuous latent variables", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we show how to use a variational approximation to the logistic function to perform approximate inference in bayesian networks containing discrete nodes with continuous parents"], ["BODY", "essentially , we convert the logistic function to a gaussian , which facilitates exact inference , and then iteratively adjust the variational parameters to improve the quality of the approximation"], ["CONCLUSION", "we demonstrate experimentally that this approximation is faster and potentially more accurate than sampling"], ["CONCLUSION", "we also introduce a simple new technique for handling evidence , which allows us to handle arbitrary distributions on observed nodes , as well as achieving a significant speedup in networks with discrete variables of large cardinality ."]], "topics": ["sampling ( signal processing )", "approximation algorithm"]}
{"title": "finding algebraic structure of care in time : a deep learning approach", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "understanding the latent processes from electronic medical records could be a game changer in modern healthcare"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , the processes are complex due to the interaction between at least three dynamic components : the illness , the care and the recording practice"], ["INTRODUCTION", "existing methods are inadequate in capturing the dynamic structure of care"], ["BODY", "we propose an end-to-end model that reads medical record and predicts future risk"], ["BODY", "the model adopts the algebraic view in that discrete medical objects are embedded into continuous vectors lying in the same space"], ["BODY", "the bag of disease and comorbidities recorded at each hospital visit are modeled as function of sets"], ["BODY", "the same holds for the bag of treatments"], ["BODY", "the interaction between diseases and treatments at a visit is modeled as the residual of the diseases minus the treatments"], ["BODY", "finally , the health trajectory , which is a sequence of visits , is modeled using a recurrent neural network"], ["CONCLUSION", "we report preliminary results on chronic diseases - diabetes and mental health - for predicting unplanned readmission ."]], "topics": ["recurrent neural network", "end-to-end principle"]}
{"title": "experiments with neural networks for small and large scale authorship verification", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose two models for a special case of authorship verification problem"], ["BODY", "the task is to investigate whether the two documents of a given pair are written by the same author"], ["BODY", "we consider the authorship verification problem for both small and large scale datasets"], ["BODY", "the underlying small-scale problem has two main challenges : first , the authors of the documents are unknown to us because no previous writing samples are available"], ["BODY", "second , the two documents are short ( a few hundred to a few thousand words ) and may differ considerably in the genre and/or topic"], ["BODY", "to solve it we propose transformation encoder to transform one document of the pair into the other"], ["BODY", "this document transformation generates a loss which is used as a recognizable feature to verify if the authors of the pair are identical"], ["BODY", "for the large scale problem where various authors are engaged and more examples are available with larger length , a parallel recurrent neural network is proposed"], ["BODY", "it compares the language models of the two documents"], ["CONCLUSION", "we evaluate our methods on various types of datasets including authorship identification datasets of pan competition , amazon reviews , and machine learning articles"], ["CONCLUSION", "experiments show that both methods achieve stable and competitive performance compared to the baselines ."]], "topics": ["baseline ( configuration management )", "recurrent neural network"]}
{"title": "embedding deep networks into visual explanations", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in this paper , we propose a novel explanation module to explain the predictions made by deep learning"], ["BODY", "explanation modules work by embedding a high-dimensional deep network layer nonlinearly into a low-dimensional explanation space , while retaining faithfulness in that the original deep learning predictions can be constructed from the few concepts extracted by the explanation module"], ["BODY", "we then visualize such concepts so that human can learn about the high-level concepts deep learning is using to make decisions"], ["BODY", "we propose an algorithm called sparse reconstruction autoencoder ( srae ) for learning the embedding to the explanation space , srae aims to reconstruct part of the original feature space while retaining faithfulness"], ["BODY", "a visualization system is then introduced for human understanding of features in the explanation space"], ["BODY", "the proposed method is applied to explain cnn models in image classification tasks , and several novel metrics are introduced to evaluate the performance of explanations quantitatively without human involvement"], ["CONCLUSION", "experiments show that the proposed approach could generate better explanations of the mechanisms cnn use for making predictions in the task ."]], "topics": ["feature vector", "high- and low-level"]}
{"title": "communication-efficient distributed estimation and inference for transelliptical graphical models", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose communication-efficient distributed estimation and inference methods for the transelliptical graphical model , a semiparametric extension of the elliptical distribution in the high dimensional regime"], ["BODY", "in detail , the proposed method distributes the $ d $ -dimensional data of size $ n $ generated from a transelliptical graphical model into $ m $ worker machines , and estimates the latent precision matrix on each worker machine based on the data of size $ n=n/m $"], ["BODY", "it then debiases the local estimators on the worker machines and send them back to the master machine"], ["BODY", "finally , on the master machine , it aggregates the debiased local estimators by averaging and hard thresholding"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show that the aggregated estimator attains the same statistical rate as the centralized estimator based on all the data , provided that the number of machines satisfies $ m \\lesssim \\min\\ { n\\log d/d , \\sqrt { n/ ( s^2\\log d ) } \\ } $ , where $ s $ is the maximum number of nonzero entries in each column of the latent precision matrix"], ["CONCLUSION", "it is worth noting that our algorithm and theory can be directly applied to gaussian graphical models , gaussian copula graphical models and elliptical graphical models , since they are all special cases of transelliptical graphical models"], ["CONCLUSION", "thorough experiments on synthetic data back up our theory ."]], "topics": ["graphical model", "synthetic data"]}

{"title": "on the statistical efficiency of $ \\ell_ { 1 , p } $ multi-task learning of gaussian graphical models", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in this paper , we present $ \\ell_ { 1 , p } $ multi-task structure learning for gaussian graphical models"], ["BODY", "we analyze the sufficient number of samples for the correct recovery of the support union and edge signs"], ["BODY", "we also analyze the necessary number of samples for any conceivable method by providing information-theoretic lower bounds"], ["BODY", "we compare the statistical efficiency of multi-task learning versus that of single-task learning"], ["BODY", "for experiments , we use a block coordinate descent method that is provably convergent and generates a sequence of positive definite solutions"], ["CONCLUSION", "we provide experimental validation on synthetic data as well as on two publicly available real-world data sets , including functional magnetic resonance imaging and gene expression data ."]], "topics": ["graphical model", "optimization problem"]}
{"title": "monte-carlo optimizations for resource allocation problems in stochastic network systems", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "real-world distributed systems and networks are often unreliable and subject to random failures of its components"], ["INTRODUCTION", "such a stochastic behavior affects adversely the complexity of optimization tasks performed routinely upon such systems , in particular , various resource allocation tasks"], ["BODY", "in this work we investigate and develop monte carlo solutions for a class of two-stage optimization problems in stochastic networks in which the expected value of resource allocations before and after stochastic failures needs to be optimized"], ["BODY", "the limitation of these problems is that their exact solutions are exponential in the number of unreliable network components : thus , exact methods do not scale-up well to large networks often seen in practice"], ["BODY", "we first prove that monte carlo optimization methods can overcome the exponential bottleneck of exact methods"], ["CONCLUSION", "next we support our theoretical findings on resource allocation experiments and show a very good scale-up potential of the new methods to large stochastic networks ."]], "topics": ["time complexity"]}
{"title": "earl : joint entity and relation linking for question answering over knowledge graphs", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in order to answer natural language questions over knowledge graphs , most processing pipelines involve entity and relation linking"], ["INTRODUCTION", "traditionally , entity linking and relation linking has been performed either as dependent sequential tasks or independent parallel tasks"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we propose a framework called `` earl '' , which performs entity linking and relation linking as a joint single task"], ["BODY", "earl uses a graph connection based solution to the problem"], ["BODY", "we model the linking task as an instance of the generalised travelling salesman problem ( gtsp ) and use gtsp approximate algorithm solutions"], ["BODY", "we later develop earl which uses a pair-wise graph-distance based solution to the problem.the system determines the best semantic connection between all keywords of the question by referring to a knowledge graph"], ["BODY", "this is achieved by exploiting the `` connection density '' between entity candidates and relation candidates"], ["CONCLUSION", "the `` connection density '' based solution performs at par with the approximate gtsp solution.we have empirically evaluated the framework on a dataset with 5000 questions"], ["CONCLUSION", "our system surpasses state-of-the-art scores for entity linking task by reporting an accuracy of 0.65 to 0.40 from the next best entity linker ."]], "topics": ["natural language processing", "natural language"]}
{"title": "automatic visual theme discovery from joint image and text corpora", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "a popular approach to semantic image understanding is to manually tag images with keywords and then learn a mapping from vi- sual features to keywords"], ["INTRODUCTION", "manually tagging images is a subjective pro- cess and the same or very similar visual contents are often tagged with different keywords"], ["INTRODUCTION", "furthermore , not all tags have the same descriptive power for visual contents and large vocabulary available from natural language could result in a very diverse set of keywords"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we propose an unsupervised visual theme discovery framework as a better ( more compact , efficient and effective ) alternative to semantic represen- tation of visual contents"], ["BODY", "we first show that tag based annotation lacks consistency and compactness for describing visually similar contents"], ["BODY", "we then learn the visual similarity between tags based on the visual features of the images containing the tags"], ["BODY", "at the same time , we use a natural language processing technique ( word embedding ) to measure the seman- tic similarity between tags"], ["BODY", "finally , we cluster tags into visual themes based on their visual similarity and semantic similarity measures using a spectral clustering algorithm"], ["CONCLUSION", "we conduct user studies to evaluate the effectiveness and rationality of the visual themes discovered by our unsu- pervised algorithm and obtains promising result"], ["CONCLUSION", "we then design three common computer vision tasks , example based image search , keyword based image search and image labelling to explore potential applica- tion of our visual themes discovery framework"], ["CONCLUSION", "in experiments , visual themes significantly outperforms tags on semantic image understand- ing and achieve state-of-art performance in all three tasks"], ["CONCLUSION", "this again demonstrate the effectiveness and versatility of proposed framework ."]], "topics": ["cluster analysis", "unsupervised learning"]}

{"title": "the influence of intensity standardization on medical image registration", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "acquisition-to-acquisition signal intensity variations ( non-standardness ) are inherent in mr images"], ["INTRODUCTION", "standardization is a post processing method for correcting inter-subject intensity variations through transforming all images from the given image gray scale into a standard gray scale wherein similar intensities achieve similar tissue meanings"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the lack of a standard image intensity scale in mri leads to many difficulties in tissue characterizability , image display , and analysis , including image segmentation"], ["INTRODUCTION", "this phenomenon has been documented well ; however , effects of standardization on medical image registration have not been studied yet"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we investigate the influence of intensity standardization in registration tasks with systematic and analytic evaluations involving clinical mr images"], ["BODY", "we conducted nearly 20,000 clinical mr image registration experiments and evaluated the quality of registrations both quantitatively and qualitatively"], ["CONCLUSION", "the evaluations show that intensity variations between images degrades the accuracy of registration performance"], ["CONCLUSION", "the results imply that the accuracy of image registration not only depends on spatial and geometric similarity but also on the similarity of the intensity values for the same tissues in different images ."]], "topics": ["image segmentation"]}

progressive disease , such as cancer or alzheimer 's"], ["BODY", "progressive diseases often start with mild symptoms that might precede a diagnosis , and each patient follows their own trajectory"], ["BODY", "patient trajectories exhibit wild variability , which can be associated with many factors such as genotype , age , or sex"], ["BODY", "an additional layer of complexity is that , in real life , the amount and type of data available for each patient can differ significantly"], ["BODY", "for example , for one patient we might have no prior history , whereas for another patient we might have detailed clinical assessments obtained at multiple prior time-points"], ["BODY", "this paper presents a probabilistic model that can handle multiple modalities ( including images and clinical assessments ) and variable patient histories with irregular timings and missing entries , to predict clinical scores at future time-points"], ["BODY", "we use a sigmoidal function to model latent disease progression , which gives rise to clinical observations in our generative model"], ["BODY", "we implemented an approximate bayesian inference strategy on the proposed model to estimate the parameters on data from a large population of subjects"], ["BODY", "furthermore , the bayesian framework enables the model to automatically fine-tune its predictions based on historical observations that might be available on the test subject"], ["CONCLUSION", "we applied our method to a longitudinal alzheimer 's disease dataset with more than 3000 subjects [ 23 ] and present a detailed empirical analysis of prediction performance under different scenarios , with comparisons against several benchmarks"], ["CONCLUSION", "we also demonstrate how the proposed model can be interrogated to glean insights about temporal dynamics in alzheimer 's disease ."]], "topics": ["generative model", "approximation algorithm"]}
{"title": "man is to computer programmer as woman is to homemaker ? debiasing word embeddings", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the blind application of machine learning runs the risk of amplifying biases present in data"], ["INTRODUCTION", "such a danger is facing us with word embedding , a popular framework to represent text data as vectors which has been used in many machine learning and natural language processing tasks"], ["BODY", "we show that even word embeddings trained on google news articles exhibit female/male gender stereotypes to a disturbing extent"], ["BODY", "this raises concerns because their widespread use , as we describe , often tends to amplify these biases"], ["BODY", "geometrically , gender bias is first shown to be captured by a direction in the word embedding"], ["BODY", "second , gender neutral words are shown to be linearly separable from gender definition words in the word embedding"], ["BODY", "using these properties , we provide a methodology for modifying an embedding to remove gender stereotypes , such as the association between between the words receptionist and female , while maintaining desired associations such as between the words queen and female"], ["BODY", "we define metrics to quantify both direct and indirect gender biases in embeddings , and develop algorithms to `` debias '' the embedding"], ["CONCLUSION", "using crowd-worker evaluation as well as standard benchmarks , we empirically demonstrate that our algorithms significantly reduce gender bias in embeddings while preserving the its useful properties such as the ability to cluster related concepts and to solve analogy tasks"], ["CONCLUSION", "the resulting embeddings can be used in applications without amplifying gender bias ."]], "topics": ["natural language processing", "text corpus"]}
{"title": "neural decomposition of time-series data for effective generalization", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we present a neural network technique for the analysis and extrapolation of time-series data called neural decomposition ( nd )"], ["BODY", "units with a sinusoidal activation function are used to perform a fourier-like decomposition of training samples into a sum of sinusoids , augmented by units with nonperiodic activation functions to capture linear trends and other nonperiodic components"], ["BODY", "we show how careful weight initialization can be combined with regularization to form a simple model that generalizes well"], ["CONCLUSION", "our method generalizes effectively on the mackey-glass series , a dataset of unemployment rates as reported by the u.s. department of labor statistics , a time-series of monthly international airline passengers , the monthly ozone concentration in downtown los angeles , and an unevenly sampled time-series of oxygen isotope measurements from a cave in north india"], ["CONCLUSION", "we find that nd outperforms popular time-series forecasting techniques including lstm , echo state networks , arima , sarima , svr with a radial basis function , and gashler and ashmore 's model ."]], "topics": ["time series", "support vector machine"]}
{"title": "recursion-free online multiple incremental/decremental analysis based on ridge support vector learning", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "this study presents a rapid multiple incremental and decremental mechanism based on weight-error curves ( wecs ) for support-vector analysis"], ["BODY", "recursion-free computation is proposed for predicting the lagrangian multipliers of new samples"], ["BODY", "this study examines ridge support vector models , subsequently devising a recursion-free function derived from wecs"], ["BODY", "with the proposed function , all the new lagrangian multipliers can be computed at once without using any gradual step sizes"], ["BODY", "moreover , such a function relaxes a constraint , where the increment of new multiple lagrangian multipliers should be the same in the previous work , thereby easily satisfying the requirement of kkt conditions"], ["CONCLUSION", "the proposed mechanism no longer requires typical bookkeeping strategies , which compute the step size by checking all the training samples in each incremental round ."]], "topics": ["baseline ( configuration management )", "support vector machine"]}
{"title": "approximate inference with the variational holder bound", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we introduce the variational holder ( vh ) bound as an alternative to variational bayes ( vb ) for approximate bayesian inference"], ["BODY", "unlike vb which typically involves maximization of a non-convex lower bound with respect to the variational parameters , the vh bound involves minimization of a convex upper bound to the intractable integral with respect to the variational parameters"], ["BODY", "minimization of the vh bound is a convex optimization problem ; hence the vh method can be applied using off-the-shelf convex optimization algorithms and the approximation error of the vh bound can also be analyzed using tools from convex optimization literature"], ["CONCLUSION", "we present experiments on the task of integrating a truncated multivariate gaussian distribution and compare our method to vb , ep and a state-of-the-art numerical integration method for this problem ."]], "topics": ["optimization problem", "calculus of variations"]}
{"title": "image restoration using autoencoding priors", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose to leverage denoising autoencoder networks as priors to address image restoration problems"], ["BODY", "we build on the key observation that the output of an optimal denoising autoencoder is a local mean of the true data density , and the autoencoder error ( the difference between the output and input of the trained autoencoder ) is a mean shift vector"], ["BODY", "we use the magnitude of this mean shift vector , that is , the distance to the local mean , as the negative log likelihood of our natural image prior"], ["BODY", "for image restoration , we maximize the likelihood using gradient descent by backpropagating the autoencoder error"], ["BODY", "a key advantage of our approach is that we do not need to train separate networks for different image restoration tasks , such as non-blind deconvolution with different kernels , or super-resolution at different magnification factors"], ["CONCLUSION", "we demonstrate state of the art results for non-blind deconvolution and super-resolution using the same autoencoding prior ."]], "topics": ["noise reduction", "gradient descent"]}
{"title": "learning to refine object segments", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "object segmentation requires both object-level information and low-level pixel data"], ["INTRODUCTION", "this presents a challenge for feedforward networks : lower layers in convolutional nets capture rich spatial information , while upper layers encode object-level knowledge but are invariant to factors such as pose and appearance"], ["BODY", "in this work we propose to augment feedforward nets for object segmentation with a novel top-down refinement approach"], ["BODY", "the resulting bottom-up/top-down architecture is capable of efficiently generating high-fidelity object masks"], ["BODY", "similarly to skip connections , our approach leverages features at all layers of the net"], ["BODY", "unlike skip connections , our approach does not attempt to output independent predictions at each layer"], ["BODY", "instead , we first output a coarse `mask encoding ' in a feedforward pass , then refine this mask encoding in a top-down pass utilizing features at successively lower layers"], ["BODY", "the approach is simple , fast , and effective"], ["CONCLUSION", "building on the recent deepmask network for generating object proposals , we show accuracy improvements of 10-20 % in average recall for various setups"], ["CONCLUSION", "additionally , by optimizing the overall network architecture , our approach , which we call sharpmask , is 50 % faster than the original deepmask network ( under .8s per image ) ."]], "topics": ["high- and low-level", "pixel"]}
{"title": "object recognition system design in computer vision : a universal approach", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the first contribution of this paper is architecture of a multipurpose system , which delegates a range of object detection tasks to a classifier , applied in special grid positions of the tested image"], ["BODY", "the second contribution is gray level-radius co-occurrence matrix , which describes local image texture and topology and , unlike common second order statistics methods , is robust to image resolution"], ["BODY", "the third contribution is a parametrically controlled automatic synthesis of unlimited number of numerical features for classification"], ["BODY", "the fourth contribution is a method of optimizing parameters c and gamma in libsvm-based classifier , which is 20-100 times faster than the commonly applied method"], ["BODY", "the work is essentially experimental , with demonstration of various methods for definition of objects of interest in images and video sequences ."]], "topics": ["object detection", "numerical analysis"]}
{"title": "a chaid based performance prediction model in educational data mining", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the performance in higher secondary school education in india is a turning point in the academic lives of all students"], ["INTRODUCTION", "as this academic performance is influenced by many factors , it is essential to develop predictive data mining model for students ' performance so as to identify the slow learners and study the influence of the dominant factors on their academic performance"], ["BODY", "in the present investigation , a survey cum experimental methodology was adopted to generate a database and it was constructed from a primary and a secondary source"], ["BODY", "while the primary data was collected from the regular students , the secondary data was gathered from the school and office of the chief educational officer ( ceo )"], ["BODY", "a total of 1000 datasets of the year 2006 from five different schools in three different districts of tamilnadu were collected"], ["BODY", "the raw data was preprocessed in terms of filling up missing values , transforming values in one form into another and relevant attribute/ variable selection"], ["CONCLUSION", "as a result , we had 772 student records , which were used for chaid prediction model construction"], ["CONCLUSION", "a set of prediction rules were extracted from chiad prediction model and the efficiency of the generated chiad prediction model was found"], ["CONCLUSION", "the accuracy of the present model was compared with other model and it has been found to be satisfactory ."]], "topics": ["data mining", "value ( ethics )"]}
{"title": "adaptive parallel tempering for stochastic maximum likelihood learning of rbms", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "restricted boltzmann machines ( rbm ) have attracted a lot of attention of late , as one the principle building blocks of deep networks"], ["INTRODUCTION", "training rbms remains problematic however , because of the intractibility of their partition function"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the maximum likelihood gradient requires a very robust sampler which can accurately sample from the model despite the loss of ergodicity often incurred during learning"], ["INTRODUCTION", "while using parallel tempering in the negative phase of stochastic maximum likelihood ( sml-pt ) helps address the issue , it imposes a trade-off between computational complexity and high ergodicity , and requires careful hand-tuning of the temperatures"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we show that this trade-off is unnecessary"], ["BODY", "the choice of optimal temperatures can be automated by minimizing average return time ( a concept first proposed by [ katzgraber et al"], ["BODY", ", 2006 ] ) while chains can be spawned dynamically , as needed , thus minimizing the computational overhead"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show on a synthetic dataset , that this results in better likelihood scores ."]], "topics": ["sampling ( signal processing )", "computational complexity theory"]}
{"title": "detectability thresholds and optimal algorithms for community structure in dynamic networks", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we study the fundamental limits on learning latent community structure in dynamic networks"], ["BODY", "specifically , we study dynamic stochastic block models where nodes change their community membership over time , but where edges are generated independently at each time step"], ["BODY", "in this setting ( which is a special case of several existing models ) , we are able to derive the detectability threshold exactly , as a function of the rate of change and the strength of the communities"], ["BODY", "below this threshold , we claim that no algorithm can identify the communities better than chance"], ["BODY", "we then give two algorithms that are optimal in the sense that they succeed all the way down to this limit"], ["BODY", "the first uses belief propagation ( bp ) , which gives asymptotically optimal accuracy , and the second is a fast spectral clustering algorithm , based on linearizing the bp equations"], ["CONCLUSION", "we verify our analytic and algorithmic results via numerical simulation , and close with a brief discussion of extensions and open questions ."]], "topics": ["cluster analysis", "numerical analysis"]}

{"title": "kernel multivariate analysis framework for supervised subspace learning : a tutorial on linear and kernel multivariate methods", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "feature extraction and dimensionality reduction are important tasks in many fields of science dealing with signal processing and analysis"], ["INTRODUCTION", "the relevance of these techniques is increasing as current sensory devices are developed with ever higher resolution , and problems involving multimodal data sources become more common"], ["INTRODUCTION", "a plethora of feature extraction methods are available in the literature collectively grouped under the field of multivariate analysis ( mva )"], ["BODY", "this paper provides a uniform treatment of several methods : principal component analysis ( pca ) , partial least squares ( pls ) , canonical correlation analysis ( cca ) and orthonormalized pls ( opls ) , as well as their non-linear extensions derived by means of the theory of reproducing kernel hilbert spaces"], ["BODY", "we also review their connections to other methods for classification and statistical dependence estimation , and introduce some recent developments to deal with the extreme cases of large-scale and low-sized problems"], ["CONCLUSION", "to illustrate the wide applicability of these methods in both classification and regression problems , we analyze their performance in a benchmark of publicly available data sets , and pay special attention to specific real applications involving audio processing for music genre prediction and hyperspectral satellite images for earth and climate monitoring ."]], "topics": ["kernel ( operating system )", "image processing"]}
{"title": "direct estimation of regional wall thicknesses via residual recurrent neural network", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "accurate estimation of regional wall thicknesses ( rwt ) of left ventricular ( lv ) myocardium from cardiac mr sequences is of significant importance for identification and diagnosis of cardiac disease"], ["INTRODUCTION", "existing rwt estimation still relies on segmentation of lv myocardium , which requires strong prior information and user interaction"], ["INTRODUCTION", "no work has been devoted into direct estimation of rwt from cardiac mr images due to the diverse shapes and structures for various subjects and cardiac diseases , as well as the complex regional deformation of lv myocardium during the systole and diastole phases of the cardiac cycle"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we present a newly proposed residual recurrent neural network ( resrnn ) that fully leverages the spatial and temporal dynamics of lv myocardium to achieve accurate frame-wise rwt estimation"], ["BODY", "our resrnn comprises two paths : 1 ) a feed forward convolution neural network ( cnn ) for effective and robust cnn embedding learning of various cardiac images and preliminary estimation of rwt from each frame itself independently , and 2 ) a recurrent neural network ( rnn ) for further improving the estimation by modeling spatial and temporal dynamics of lv myocardium"], ["BODY", "for the rnn path , we design for cardiac sequences a circle-rnn to eliminate the effect of null hidden input for the first time-step"], ["CONCLUSION", "our resrnn is capable of obtaining accurate estimation of cardiac rwt with mean absolute error of 1.44mm ( less than 1-pixel error ) when validated on cardiac mr sequences of 145 subjects , evidencing its great potential in clinical cardiac function assessment ."]], "topics": ["recurrent neural network", "convolution"]}
{"title": "deep learning for passive synthetic aperture radar", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we introduce a deep learning ( dl ) framework for inverse problems in imaging , and demonstrate the advantages and applicability of this approach in passive synthetic aperture radar ( sar ) image reconstruction"], ["BODY", "we interpret image recon- struction as a machine learning task and utilize deep networks as forward and inverse solvers for imaging"], ["BODY", "specifically , we design a recurrent neural network ( rnn ) architecture as an inverse solver based on the iterations of proximal gradient descent optimization methods"], ["BODY", "we further adapt the rnn architecture to image reconstruction problems by transforming the network into a recurrent auto-encoder , thereby allowing for unsupervised training"], ["BODY", "our dl based inverse solver is particularly suitable for a class of image formation problems in which the forward model is only partially known"], ["BODY", "the ability to learn forward models and hyper parameters combined with unsupervised training approach establish our recurrent auto-encoder suitable for real world applications"], ["CONCLUSION", "we demonstrate the performance of our method in passive sar image reconstruction"], ["CONCLUSION", "in this regime a source of opportunity , with unknown location and transmitted waveform , is used to illuminate a scene of interest"], ["CONCLUSION", "we investigate recurrent auto- encoder architecture based on the 1 and 0 constrained least- squares problem"], ["CONCLUSION", "we present a projected stochastic gradient descent based training scheme which incorporates constraints of the unknown model parameters"], ["CONCLUSION", "we demonstrate through extensive numerical simulations that our dl based approach out performs conventional sparse coding methods in terms of computation and reconstructed image quality , specifically , when no information about the transmitter is available ."]], {"title": "low-dimensional embeddings for interpretable anchor-based topic inference", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the anchor words algorithm performs provably efficient topic model inference by finding an approximate convex hull in a high-dimensional word co-occurrence space"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however , the existing greedy algorithm often selects poor anchor words , reducing topic quality and interpretability"], ["BODY", "rather than finding an approximate convex hull in a high-dimensional space , we propose to find an exact convex hull in a visualizable 2- or 3-dimensional space"], ["CONCLUSION", "such low-dimensional embeddings both improve topics and clearly show users why the algorithm selects certain words ."]], "topics": ["approximation algorithm"]}
{"title": "heuristic search for structural constraints in data association", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "the research on multi-object tracking ( mot ) is essentially to solve for the data association assignment , the core of which is to design the association cost as discriminative as possible"], ["INTRODUCTION", "generally speaking , the match ambiguities caused by similar appearances of objects and the moving cameras make the data association perplexing and challenging"], ["BODY", "in this paper , we propose a new heuristic method to search for structural constraints ( hssc ) of multiple targets when solving the problem of online multi-object tracking"], ["BODY", "we believe that the internal structure among multiple targets in the adjacent frames could remain constant and stable even though the video sequences are captured by a moving camera"], ["CONCLUSION", "as a result , the structural constraints are able to cut down the match ambiguities caused by the moving cameras as well as similar appearances of the tracked objects"], ["CONCLUSION", "the proposed heuristic method aims to obtain a maximum match set under the minimum structural cost for each available match pair , which can be integrated with the raw association costs and make them more elaborate and discriminative compared with other approaches"], ["CONCLUSION", "in addition , this paper presents a new method to recover missing targets by minimizing the cost function generated from both motion and structure cues"], ["CONCLUSION", "our online multi-object tracking ( mot ) algorithm based on hssc has achieved the multi-object tracking accuracy ( mota ) of 25.0 on the public dataset 2dmot2015 [ 1 ] ."]], "topics": ["loss function", "heuristic"]}
{"title": "interpretable & explorable approximations of black box models", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we propose black box explanations through transparent approximations ( beta ) , a novel model agnostic framework for explaining the behavior of any black-box classifier by simultaneously optimizing for fidelity to the original model and interpretability of the explanation"], ["BODY", "to this end , we develop a novel objective function which allows us to learn ( with optimality guarantees ) , a small number of compact decision sets each of which explains the behavior of the black box model in unambiguous , well-defined regions of feature space"], ["BODY", "furthermore , our framework also is capable of accepting user input when generating these approximations , thus allowing users to interactively explore how the black-box model behaves in different subspaces that are of interest to the user"], ["BODY", "to the best of our knowledge , this is the first approach which can produce global explanations of the behavior of any given black box model through joint optimization of unambiguity , fidelity , and interpretability , while also allowing users to explore model behavior based on their preferences"], ["CONCLUSION", "experimental evaluation with real-world datasets and user studies demonstrates that our approach can generate highly compact , easy-to-understand , yet accurate approximations of various kinds of predictive models compared to state-of-the-art baselines ."]], "topics": ["feature vector", "optimization problem"]}
{"title": "a probabilistic generative grammar for semantic parsing", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we present a framework that couples the syntax and semantics of natural language sentences in a generative model , in order to develop a semantic parser that jointly infers the syntactic , morphological , and semantic representations of a given sentence under the guidance of background knowledge"], ["BODY", "to generate a sentence in our framework , a semantic statement is first sampled from a prior , such as from a set of beliefs in a knowledge base"], ["BODY", "given this semantic statement , a grammar probabilistically generates the output sentence"], ["BODY", "a joint semantic-syntactic parser is derived that returns the $ k $ -best semantic and syntactic parses for a given sentence"], ["BODY", "the semantic prior is flexible , and can be used to incorporate background knowledge during parsing , in ways unlike previous semantic parsing approaches"], ["CONCLUSION", "for example , semantic statements corresponding to beliefs in a knowledge base can be given higher prior probability , type-correct statements can be given somewhat lower probability , and beliefs outside the knowledge base can be given lower probability"], ["CONCLUSION", "the construction of our grammar invokes a novel application of hierarchical dirichlet processes ( hdps ) , which in turn , requires a novel and efficient inference approach"], ["CONCLUSION", "we present experimental results showing , for a simple grammar , that our parser outperforms a state-of-the-art ccg semantic parser and scales to knowledge bases with millions of beliefs ."]], "topics": ["generative model", "natural language"]}
{"title": "algorithms for analysing the temporal structure of discourse", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we describe a method for analysing the temporal structure of a discourse which takes into account the effects of tense , aspect , temporal adverbials and rhetorical structure and which minimises unnecessary ambiguity in the temporal structure"], ["BODY", "it is part of a discourse grammar implemented in carpenter 's ale formalism"], ["BODY", "the method for building up the temporal structure of the discourse combines constraints and preferences : we use constraints to reduce the number of possible structures , exploiting the hpsg type hierarchy and unification for this purpose ; and we apply preferences to choose between the remaining options using a temporal centering mechanism"], ["CONCLUSION", "we end by recommending that an underspecified representation of the structure using these techniques be used to avoid generating the temporal/rhetorical structure until higher-level information can be used to disambiguate ."]], "topics": ["artificial intelligence"]}

{"title": "gender identity and lexical variation in social media", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "we present a study of the relationship between gender , linguistic style , and social networks , using a novel corpus of 14,000 twitter users"], ["BODY", "prior quantitative work on gender often treats this social variable as a female/male binary ; we argue for a more nuanced approach"], ["BODY", "by clustering twitter users , we find a natural decomposition of the dataset into various styles and topical interests"], ["BODY", "many clusters have strong gender orientations , but their use of linguistic resources sometimes directly conflicts with the population-level language statistics"], ["BODY", "we view these clusters as a more accurate reflection of the multifaceted nature of gendered language styles"], ["BODY", "previous corpus-based work has also had little to say about individuals whose linguistic styles defy population-level gender patterns"], ["BODY", "to identify such individuals , we train a statistical classifier , and measure the classifier confidence for each individual in the dataset"], ["CONCLUSION", "examining individuals whose language does not match the classifier 's model for their gender , we find that they have social networks that include significantly fewer same-gender social connections and that , in general , social network homophily is correlated with the use of same-gender language markers"], ["CONCLUSION", "pairing computational methods and social theory thus offers a new perspective on how gender emerges as individuals position themselves relative to audiences , topics , and mainstream gender norms ."]], "topics": ["cluster analysis", "statistical classification"]}

{"title": "self-guiding multimodal lstm - when we do not have a perfect training dataset for image captioning", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "in this paper , a self-guiding multimodal lstm ( sg-lstm ) image captioning model is proposed to handle uncontrolled imbalanced real-world image-sentence dataset"], ["BODY", "we collect flickrnyc dataset from flickr as our testbed with 306,165 images and the original text descriptions uploaded by the users are utilized as the ground truth for training"], ["BODY", "descriptions in flickrnyc dataset vary dramatically ranging from short term-descriptions to long paragraph-descriptions and can describe any visual aspects , or even refer to objects that are not depicted"], ["BODY", "to deal with the imbalanced and noisy situation and to fully explore the dataset itself , we propose a novel guiding textual feature extracted utilizing a multimodal lstm ( m-lstm ) model"], ["BODY", "training of m-lstm is based on the portion of data in which the image content and the corresponding descriptions are strongly bonded"], ["BODY", "afterwards , during the training of sg-lstm on the rest training data , this guiding information serves as additional input to the network along with the image representations and the ground-truth descriptions"], ["BODY", "by integrating these input components into a multimodal block , we aim to form a training scheme with the textual information tightly coupled with the image content"], ["CONCLUSION", "the experimental results demonstrate that the proposed sg-lstm model outperforms the traditional state-of-the-art multimodal rnn captioning framework in successfully describing the key components of the input images ."]], "topics": ["test set", "ground truth"]}
{"title": "simple bayesian algorithms for best arm identification", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "this paper considers the optimal adaptive allocation of measurement effort for identifying the best among a finite set of options or designs"], ["BODY", "an experimenter sequentially chooses designs to measure and observes noisy signals of their quality with the goal of confidently identifying the best design after a small number of measurements"], ["BODY", "this paper proposes three simple and intuitive bayesian algorithms for adaptively allocating measurement effort , and formalizes a sense in which these seemingly naive rules are the best possible"], ["BODY", "one proposal is top-two probability sampling , which computes the two designs with the highest posterior probability of being optimal , and then randomizes to select among these two"], ["BODY", "one is a variant of top-two sampling which considers not only the probability a design is optimal , but the expected amount by which its quality exceeds that of other designs"], ["BODY", "the final algorithm is a modified version of thompson sampling that is tailored for identifying the best design"], ["CONCLUSION", "we prove that these simple algorithms satisfy a sharp optimality property"], ["CONCLUSION", "in a frequentist setting where the true quality of the designs is fixed , one hopes the posterior definitively identifies the optimal design , in the sense that that the posterior probability assigned to the event that some other design is optimal converges to zero as measurements are collected"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show that under the proposed algorithms this convergence occurs at an exponential rate , and the corresponding exponent is the best possible among all allocation"]], "topics": ["sampling ( signal processing )", "time complexity"]}

{"title": "dropout as a bayesian approximation : representing model uncertainty in deep learning", "abstract": [["INTRODUCTION", "deep learning tools have gained tremendous attention in applied machine learning"], ["INTRODUCTION", "however such tools for regression and classification do not capture model uncertainty"], ["INTRODUCTION", "in comparison , bayesian models offer a mathematically grounded framework to reason about model uncertainty , but usually come with a prohibitive computational cost"], ["BODY", "in this paper we develop a new theoretical framework casting dropout training in deep neural networks ( nns ) as approximate bayesian inference in deep gaussian processes"], ["CONCLUSION", "a direct result of this theory gives us tools to model uncertainty with dropout nns -- extracting information from existing models that has been thrown away so far"], ["CONCLUSION", "this mitigates the problem of representing uncertainty in deep learning without sacrificing either computational complexity or test accuracy"], ["CONCLUSION", "we perform an extensive study of the properties of dropout 's uncertainty"], ["CONCLUSION", "various network architectures and non-linearities are assessed on tasks of regression and classification , using mnist as an example"], ["CONCLUSION", "we show a considerable improvement in predictive log-likelihood and rmse compared to existing state-of-the-art methods , and finish by using dropout 's uncertainty in deep reinforcement learning ."]], "topics": ["statistical classification", "computational complexity theory"]}
